componenttextpreview: We don't share that number, but the trend has obviously been positive as we continue to vault the good portion of the credit cards as we move forward. I back it up a level and remind folks, one of the awesome things about the TripAdvisor business is that
componenttext: We don't share that number, but the trend has obviously been positive as we continue to vault the good portion of the credit cards as we move forward. I back it up a level and remind folks, one of the awesome things about the TripAdvisor business is that we have such reach, such scale, at 130 million, million shoppers a month, oh my goodness, it's phenomenal, but a lot of those shoppers were folks that had come in, taken a look and leave and all we would know about them is their IP address. And we built a wonderful business over 1.5 decades doing that. But with IB, sort of with Instant Booking, because we're now taking the transaction, all of those folks, if they weren't already members, are now becoming members as part of that process and we get to remarket to them, remind them that we exist, build more of the transaction loyalty. So again, that pays dividends for quite some time and, obviously, is a significant benefit of shifting or augmenting our meta model to be transactional.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and a quick follow-up that's totally unrelated. But as you go to Europe and you now have Priceline on Instant Book, obviously, they're a big bidder with booking.com in European hotels on meta. Has it affected -- is them being in Instant Book affect
componenttext: Great, and a quick follow-up that's totally unrelated. But as you go to Europe and you now have Priceline on Instant Book, obviously, they're a big bidder with booking.com in European hotels on meta. Has it affected -- is them being in Instant Book affected their meta auction pricing or behaviors?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I couldn't possibly answer from the perspective of what goes on inside of their companies and how they're choosing to bid on TripAdvisor, sorry. We point to a meta auction in the first quarter and, say, it was a very healthy auction. We have nice competit
componenttext: I couldn't possibly answer from the perspective of what goes on inside of their companies and how they're choosing to bid on TripAdvisor, sorry. We point to a meta auction in the first quarter and, say, it was a very healthy auction. We have nice competition across our partner set. We in turn launched some additional capabilities to our partners in terms of enabling them to retarget using our platform. So it's a great opportunity and a number of partners have started taking advantage of it. It's, again, just another piece of -- another sign of commitment that we have, that we're showing our partners to the meta auction building in this type of technology that allows them to bid more effectively and get the type of traffic that they want from our platform. So again, I couldn't comment on our partners specifically, but I can tell you that the meta auction is quite healthy right now.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Merwin of Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Merwin of Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of questions. I guess the first is on the Vacation Rentals space. They give you another acquisition there, so I guess some 800,000 listings now. And we've seen a few acquisitions in the space lately. I think it's become more attractive
componenttext: I just had a couple of questions. I guess the first is on the Vacation Rentals space. They give you another acquisition there, so I guess some 800,000 listings now. And we've seen a few acquisitions in the space lately. I think it's become more attractive to some of the larger players in the space. I guess the question is, [indiscernible]that you do see more competition, can you talk about what that mean for the cost of customer acquisition particularly with SCM and perhaps the long-term margin for the business? And then just another question on macro, and apologies if this had been asked, but Priceline had mentioned they had some micro concerns, so just curious what impact, if any, you've seen from that apart from the headwinds you had from Instant Book?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: While there has been some movement at your side with some of the other companies, I don't see the competitive landscape has having meaningfully changed. No particular reason to think being part of Expedia, the [indiscernible] companies will be behaving me
componenttext: While there has been some movement at your side with some of the other companies, I don't see the competitive landscape has having meaningfully changed. No particular reason to think being part of Expedia, the [indiscernible] companies will be behaving meaningfully differently. They're changing their business model but really little hard for me to see meaningful change in our cost of traffic acquisition or margins there.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would add is what you see is some of the smaller players are subscale at the moment. And the reason why we're making some of these acquisitions is because we see great scale benefits in adding some of these smaller players on to our platform.
componenttext: What I would add is what you see is some of the smaller players are subscale at the moment. And the reason why we're making some of these acquisitions is because we see great scale benefits in adding some of these smaller players on to our platform.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we are one of the sort of big players in the vacation rental space. We view it as a great alternative lodging type. As you know -- as you will know, it's perfect for a certain type of traveler looking in a certain type of location. And we aim to -- and
componenttext: So we are one of the sort of big players in the vacation rental space. We view it as a great alternative lodging type. As you know -- as you will know, it's perfect for a certain type of traveler looking in a certain type of location. And we aim to -- and we have been quite successful in fulfilling that need. For the question of sort of macro conditions, there was  what we believe to be a small [indiscernible] impact from Brussels and the overall macro issues aren't something that is keeping us up at night.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Robert Peck of SunTrust. We'll go to our next question from Douglas Anmuth of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Robert Peck of SunTrust. We'll go to our next question from Douglas Anmuth of JPMorgan.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you've talked about attractions as being potentially your next $1 billion. I was hoping if it could get an early read on how you're thinking about Instant Book so far in attractions. I know the launch is pretty recent. And also if you can talk abou
componenttext: Steve, you've talked about attractions as being potentially your next $1 billion. I was hoping if it could get an early read on how you're thinking about Instant Book so far in attractions. I know the launch is pretty recent. And also if you can talk about that space in Instant Book in particular just from a structural kind of dynamics and the degree to which that's much less competitive, perhaps, than what you're doing in terms of straight hotels. And then also on the mix between meta and Instant Book over time, any thoughts long term on how you think the mix of those 2 could shake out?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, those were 2 excellent questions. So I absolutely think attractions is a phenomenal business for us going forward. We're so well positioned because of the number of folks currently using the TripAdvisor app in market. And then you combine th
componenttext: Thanks, Doug, those were 2 excellent questions. So I absolutely think attractions is a phenomenal business for us going forward. We're so well positioned because of the number of folks currently using the TripAdvisor app in market. And then you combine that with the supply that Viator already had before we made the acquisition and then the tremendous effort of that team, super kudos to that team for picking up that much more supply on a regular repeatable basis. And we're by no means done, but we've now aggregated, we think, the best supplier footprint around the globe. That's [indiscernible] the rest demand footprint around the globe, and we think this is an awesome, awesome business to be in. It's a pain in the neck to aggregate all of the individual suppliers, many of whom aren't using a lot of technology, with a lot of individual pieces along the way, again one of the reasons why we enter the space via the supply piece via acquisition. But how that we have it, now that a lot is bookable online instantly, now that we've learned how to match it with the TripAdvisor demand, not only on the phone for Instant Booking for attractions but on the desktop for Instant Booking and attractions. And you look at a business with a margin profile that's quite similar to hotels, and like, all the ingredients are there, and it's not to say that we're the leader in every single market. It's not to say that it's straight sailing from here to there. We certainly have competition, but it's a natural fit for what travelers currently turn to TripAdvisor for. We have global reach and we have global supply in a nice margin business with some competitors, but it's not like we're coming behind in any shape or in any sense. So that's my short thesis to the $1 billion business because it's a market that, as you know, is phenomenally sized by itself. To the second question on sort of Instant Book versus meta in the longer-term mix, obviously, we expect Instant Book share to grow as we continue to roll it out, as we drive more repeat usage. But I really don't foresee the time when meta is an afterthought and it's just Instant Booking. I think there will be a large segment of the consumer base that has loyalty to a brand direct or an OTA or another OTA, one of our other clients, and they're very comfortable keeping that booking path, if you will, and TripAdvisor hopefully will facilitate that preference be it directly with the brand in Instant Book for the brand online or any of the OTA partners. And we would hope that a number of OTA partners around the globe would wish to participate in our Instant Book marketplace, as Priceline and Get a Room and others have. So I don't model out a specific, but I do expect IB to grow and I would never expect meta to disappear.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Stephen Ju of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Stephen Ju of Crdit Suisse.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think most of the questions have been answered. I want to go back to your perspective on your restaurant business and your long-term potential there and how you may be looking to differentiate it versus OpenTable or how you might look to grow it
componenttext: Steve, I think most of the questions have been answered. I want to go back to your perspective on your restaurant business and your long-term potential there and how you may be looking to differentiate it versus OpenTable or how you might look to grow it globally.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, for the question. So restaurants, a large component of our traffic is currently on restaurants. We've been investing over the past year and kind of building up the usefulness of the product, both expanding the number of restaurants that we
componenttext: Thanks, Steve, for the question. So restaurants, a large component of our traffic is currently on restaurants. We've been investing over the past year and kind of building up the usefulness of the product, both expanding the number of restaurants that we have all around the globe. We have a lot of restaurant reviews and info and engagement with restaurant owners around the globe, and we really haven't paid all that much attention to it product-wise prior -- from a minor monetization-wise prior to LaFourchette to us purchasing LaFourchette. We feel on the restaurant reservations basis that the model that OpenTable has, we have the model enhanced with discounts in other parts of the world and geographically tends to be shaping up as OpenTable is super strong in their set of markets and TheFork or LaFourchette is super strong in our set of markets. And it's hard for one to make an inroad into the other in any direction. But that's not the only thing that we view. I presume OpenTable can do in the restaurant space. So we have a lot of traffic, we have a lot of eyeballs, we have a lot of app downloads, we have a lot of users engaging in learning about restaurants. We look at it as not only how can we help users find the best restaurant, how can we help users come back to TripAdvisor more and more often, leveraging the fact that they may only -- or noting the fact that they may only travel a few times a year but they're actually eating out several times a month. And how can we leverage that sort of restaurant used case to drive overall adoption and engagement of our app. And those plans have been in place, and that's in part why we continue to invest in that category, not just the reservations piece but the whole restaurants as part of the TripAdvisor solution.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Tom White of Macquarie.
componenttext: The next question is from Tom White of Macquarie.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: One just question on marketing or kind of driving awareness of Instant Booking, Steve, you mentioned the sweepstakes and the coupon. But I guess maybe those seem to me like sort of relatively low-profile marketing maybe or may be lower impact, is that fai
componenttext: One just question on marketing or kind of driving awareness of Instant Booking, Steve, you mentioned the sweepstakes and the coupon. But I guess maybe those seem to me like sort of relatively low-profile marketing maybe or may be lower impact, is that fair? But I was hoping maybe you can talk about more significant investment to promote Instant Booking? Or maybe is that part of the kind of the phase 4 strategy once optimization of kind of the path is exactly where you guys want it. And then just secondarily, Steve, you talked about price as kind of a critical factor in terms of whether people choose IB or meta. Do you guys have sort of flexibility or ability to kind of improve kind of the way prices look? Or is that not really something you can influence?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Two good questions. Thanks. So on the marketing side, we do believe that we can make significant inroads in any particular market by focusing on the audience that is already in travel research and purchase mode, and we have 100-plus million of those
componenttext: Sure. Two good questions. Thanks. So on the marketing side, we do believe that we can make significant inroads in any particular market by focusing on the audience that is already in travel research and purchase mode, and we have 100-plus million of those already on our site in any given month. So that's a lot of traffic and we really want them to hone that message. So I wouldn't put, or at least we don't think of, our on-site promotions as kind of small or kind of not being able to move the needle for us in terms of awareness. U.S. is where we're sort of choosing to focus now because the product is more mature, the pricing is the best and we've had longer to tune the user experience. So I'd say steady as she goes from a marketing perspective on teaching folks to do -- to trial Instant Book as we improve their ability to come back and use Instant Book again. In terms of price, we don't -- as you know, we don't take the booking ourselves from a charging the credit card perspective. We're taking all of this information and we're sending it along to our Instant Book partner, be it the independent hotel, the brand or the OTA. So we don't have the ability, which was not to create the ability, to offer a price discount ourselves. We have no interest in having our OTA -- or we're looking to offer the best price that is out there on the web via the TripAdvisor Instant Book strategy. So no matter who the OTA is, no matter who the individual hoteliers, come put your pricing in our Instant Book environment, and therefore, we'll be able to offer it as the best. And if we don't have the best, well, our meta offering -- if you're a meta partner can also show an even better price than IB, and you do see that on the site sometimes. Pricing, as any OTA will tell you, is a longtail game. There's no one magic bullet. No one site out there has the absolute best pricing anywhere, but that is in the Holy Grail that everyone looks for and we're no exception to that. We think our model is extremely well suited to being able to offer consumers the best pricing period full stop via meta, and great pricing in almost all cases using our Instant Book initiative where we've stored the credit cards or building user convenience to come back because you'll always find the best price, but that takes a while and we wouldn't be trying to do that by offering sort of price discounts on our end because we're not the merchant on record.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Robert Peck of SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question is from Robert Peck of SunTrust.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry about the issues there. I'm not sure what it was. A couple of quick questions if you don't mind. One is, Google has rolled out a product on mobile, and we're just curious if you're seeing any impact from that. And then number two, following up on Ch
componenttext: Sorry about the issues there. I'm not sure what it was. A couple of quick questions if you don't mind. One is, Google has rolled out a product on mobile, and we're just curious if you're seeing any impact from that. And then number two, following up on Chris' macro question, particularly we are curious on the RevPAR side of things, if you're seeing RevPAR pressures impact your business at all.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Robert. So Google's been doing a lot over the years, quite a few years now in the travel space. What can I say, they continue to try to get into the travel space. They have a phenomenal ability with their search engine to direct traffic to their own
componenttext: Sure, Robert. So Google's been doing a lot over the years, quite a few years now in the travel space. What can I say, they continue to try to get into the travel space. They have a phenomenal ability with their search engine to direct traffic to their own products even when their consumers demonstrably do not like that. For this particular product, the new mobile offering, I'd say way too early for anyone to have a meaningful opinion on it. It's not really kind of likely, in my opinion, to have a big impact on the transaction components of a site. It's way up in the discovery set, but time will tell whether they will continue to invest in that. On the RevPAR, we tend, as a business, not to track our financials on RevPAR. We look at how -- we look at our top of funnel metrics, how many people can we get in the store and how quickly can we convert them as, fundamentally, RevPAR isn't something that we have any control over.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Kevin Kopelman of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Kevin Kopelman of Cowen and Company.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, could you just give us a better sense, if you haven't already, on the Q2 revenue growth projection versus the Q1 in the Hotel segment? Should we expect bigger declines in their versus -- compared to Q1 just given the rollout? And then just a follow
componenttext: First, could you just give us a better sense, if you haven't already, on the Q2 revenue growth projection versus the Q1 in the Hotel segment? Should we expect bigger declines in their versus -- compared to Q1 just given the rollout? And then just a follow-up on HouseTrip, can you give us any more metrics what the acquisition price was and the contribution expected this year?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Kevin, this is Ernst. As you know, we are not giving specific guidance for the full year nor for the second quarter. However, we did 3 months ago, and we're reiterating that described the pattern of the year, and what we described is, in the first ha
componenttext: Hey, Kevin, this is Ernst. As you know, we are not giving specific guidance for the full year nor for the second quarter. However, we did 3 months ago, and we're reiterating that described the pattern of the year, and what we described is, in the first half of the year, we expect revenue deceleration, and you've seen that in Q1. And in the back of of the year, we're going to see revenue growth rates expand again. And that is as much as we want to comment on the profile for the year. In terms of HouseTrip, we have not disclosed a purchase price for HouseTrip which, in itself, indicates that it wasn't very material, and the impact it will make will be helpful for our Vacation Rentals business but not significantly material for their overall financial results for the year.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Peter Stabler of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Next question is from Peter Stabler of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to go back to IB meta. If we think about the desktop experience in the U.S. versus the mobile experience, consumers coming into the funnel, can you give us a sense of the preference for IB versus meta, how it might differ on the desktop versus the
componenttext: Wanted to go back to IB meta. If we think about the desktop experience in the U.S. versus the mobile experience, consumers coming into the funnel, can you give us a sense of the preference for IB versus meta, how it might differ on the desktop versus the mobile? And then secondly, wondering if -- on a separate topic, wondering if you could comment on loyalty programs. Is an expansion of loyalty program activity by various partners a threat to Trip? There's obviously different opinions among your partners on how valuable they are. Wonder if you could offer your thoughts on that topic.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. Yes, we do see a meaningful difference in IB adoption on desktop versus phone. Not surprisingly, Instant Book is used a lot more and represents a higher percentage of our phone revenue. There are credit card vault rate, as we call it, how many
componenttext: Certainly. Yes, we do see a meaningful difference in IB adoption on desktop versus phone. Not surprisingly, Instant Book is used a lot more and represents a higher percentage of our phone revenue. There are credit card vault rate, as we call it, how many people store their credit card after the transaction, it's much higher on the phone. Credit card usage or vaulted credit card usage rate is higher on the phone, again, all kind of after-the-fact evidence that having Instant Book on the phone, as people move more and more their transactions to the phone, is a good thing to have, we believe a requirement to have to be a credible offering in the future. So yes, we see a difference, and yes, it's kind of as expected. The second question is, are loyalty programs a threat? Yes, every program that tries to drive a consumer to go straight to a booking site that's not TripAdvisor is taking customer that we would like to service and making them loyal somewhere else. We know they've been around for a long time. Some of the biggest players don't have them and seem to be doing great. So I obviously have no inside knowledge, but I would assume those programs would continue to grow in terms of visibility and everyone has some set of reasons why a secret deal here or there as to why one might want to go back to the site. TripAdvisor has our set of reasons why you want to come to TripAdvisor, namely the incredible content, the candid photos, the room tips, to being able to compare all the prices because nobody wants a secret deal on a particular site if, in fact, that's not better than what you can find elsewhere. And of course, through Instant Book or through meta, we can allow our clients to offer their special deals or their special offers to our audience as well should they choose. We don't think the dynamics around consumer loyalty have changed all that much over the last set of years. So while it's on the horizon, it's not something that I think will materially change behavior over the next several years.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jeff Kelly of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: The next question is from Jeff Kelly of Oppenheimer.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where are you in terms of launching your own retargeting product? And besides generating additional revenue for your metasearch partners from this product, can developing an internal retargeting product potentially ease some of the reason to leverage an o
componenttext: Where are you in terms of launching your own retargeting product? And besides generating additional revenue for your metasearch partners from this product, can developing an internal retargeting product potentially ease some of the reason to leverage an online advertising?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not entirely sure the question. I can tell you what you do and then I'll tell you what we do and then I'll ask you for a follow-up, if it's not clear. So we, currently, for our online marketing campaigns, leverage retargeting as we buy TripAdvisor
componenttext: So I'm not entirely sure the question. I can tell you what you do and then I'll tell you what we do and then I'll ask you for a follow-up, if it's not clear. So we, currently, for our online marketing campaigns, leverage retargeting as we buy TripAdvisor traffic that left TripAdvisor and is on other third-party sites, and we buy them back with banner ads and search retargeting. From what we offer our clients, if a visitor is on a site, for instance, Expedia, then are visiting TripAdvisor, we allow the client to bid differently in the meta auction in order to reflect the fact that, that visitor may be worth more or less than the average visitor they get from TripAdvisor. And that's rolled out and more and more partners are adopting that, just as a way to optimize their bidding strategy exactly in the same way that TripAdvisor looks to optimize our bidding strategy when we acquire traffic to our site, much the same sort of on a conceptual basis for how that's done.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I guess my question was more around as you develop more of an internal retargeting product, can that potentially ease some of the reliance on some of the third party tech platform you use?
componenttext: I'm sorry, I guess my question was more around as you develop more of an internal retargeting product, can that potentially ease some of the reliance on some of the third party tech platform you use?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The third-party ad tech platforms that we use to acquired traffic to TripAdvisor?
componenttext: The third-party ad tech platforms that we use to acquired traffic to TripAdvisor?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, such as [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes, such as [indiscernible].

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean I don't -- the platform that we have developed is for our clients to use re-buying or remarketing to the traffic that was on their site and is now on TripAdvisor. [indiscernible] aware anyone else, they can't do that, they can't offer that. Tha
componenttext: No. I mean I don't -- the platform that we have developed is for our clients to use re-buying or remarketing to the traffic that was on their site and is now on TripAdvisor. [indiscernible] aware anyone else, they can't do that, they can't offer that. That's something that we have to offer ourselves. And then since we buy traffic elsewhere on the web, we're not trying to get into the business that [indiscernible] is in by way of a broad ad tech platform. We have a huge audience. We will offer to our CPM clients the ability to buy, to spend on TripAdvisor and buy a banner ad for Hilton, for instance, that is placed on TripAdvisor and is also placed on a third-party sites to a visitor that was on TripAdvisor. So we do offer that. It's a growing part of our business. It's a nice part of our business. It doesn't really affect our reliance on other ad tech platforms one way or the other.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of building out the content with respect to IB attractions or Vacation Rentals or any one of your kind of channels, to what extent is that both a joint exercise on your part but also in conjunction with your partners? And then 2 quick ones. Can y
componenttext: In terms of building out the content with respect to IB attractions or Vacation Rentals or any one of your kind of channels, to what extent is that both a joint exercise on your part but also in conjunction with your partners? And then 2 quick ones. Can you remind us what the exclusivity concerns are around booking.com and their IB relationship? When do those expire? And then as you embark in Phase 3 of your IB road map, how long do you envision that phase kind of playing out?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm not sure I quite followed on the partnership piece. When we kind of add content, the room description, room tips, we're doing that ourselves. If the content you're referring to is more pricing and more availability of rooms, well, that's our sup
componenttext: Sure. I'm not sure I quite followed on the partnership piece. When we kind of add content, the room description, room tips, we're doing that ourselves. If the content you're referring to is more pricing and more availability of rooms, well, that's our supply footprint for hotels or attractions or restaurants. And we have our teams going out and getting more and more supply. With that supply comes just more choice in rooms and tours and attractions. So with our partners, well, you can ask a follow-up if I'm missing a point on that one, we don't really comment on partner contracts with respect to things like the booking.com contract. You've seen more and more suppliers be added to our Instant Book offering over time, and we continue to add partners every single quarter. So we have a lot of flexibility to deliver the product that we want to our customers. Was there something in the partner contracts I missed?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the last one, Steve, was just, as you embark on Phase 3, have you talked about how long you envision Phase 3 playing out?
componenttext: No, the last one, Steve, was just, as you embark on Phase 3, have you talked about how long you envision Phase 3 playing out?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The phases are meant kind of as guideposts. We're certainly already doing a little bit of Phase 4 right now because we're trying to get people to do more and more repeat bookings, that's great. We've been improving the experience, educating folks which is
componenttext: The phases are meant kind of as guideposts. We're certainly already doing a little bit of Phase 4 right now because we're trying to get people to do more and more repeat bookings, that's great. We've been improving the experience, educating folks which is Phase 3. We were starting that in Phase 2. So they're fuzzy, but we've articulated them because, hey, everyone had seen IB in the U.S., but we wanted to remind everyone the clock is just now starting to run on the rest of the major countries throughout the world, that's great. And this phase coming forward is less about intro, less about rollout and now about honing that user experience and driving the behavior that we want. Certainly, if you want to combine 3 and 4, the phases last forever. If you want to split them out, Phase 3 will be a while.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dan Wasiolek of Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question is from Dan Wasiolek of Morningstar.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the non-hotel segment, considering the shift to transaction and vacation rental, when we think about the progression of revenue growth for the rest of '16 into '17, should it be something similar to the commentary that you've given on the hotel side
componenttext: So in the non-hotel segment, considering the shift to transaction and vacation rental, when we think about the progression of revenue growth for the rest of '16 into '17, should it be something similar to the commentary that you've given on the hotel side?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, thanks for asking that question. We made the comment in the prepared remarks about our Vacation Rental business. What we outlined is, and this is happening in both Instant Booking and in Vacation Rentals, is as we move our business models and we
componenttext: Yes, Dan, thanks for asking that question. We made the comment in the prepared remarks about our Vacation Rental business. What we outlined is, and this is happening in both Instant Booking and in Vacation Rentals, is as we move our business models and we've talked about Instant Booking, but if you look at Vacation Rentals, we're moving our business model in Vacation Rental, we have progressively over the last year. So if you look at Q1 2015, we had a small portion of the revenues recognized on stay and other elements of revenue but recognized on book or subscription. And as we migrate it over the year, now we're in Q1 '16, we see the substantial portion of our revenues is recognized on stay. So that has a significant impact, particularly on the seasonality of our business. Q1 is a quarter in Vacation Rentals in which there are a lot of bookings for later in the year for Q2, but specifically for the summer in Q3. And so what you see, if you compare the year-on-year growth rates is what you see is that the total of 14% year-on-year growth for non-hotel, which is not just Vacation Rentals obviously, is suppressed by that impact. And as we look at outlook for the full year, we believe the growth rate for non-hotel will be significantly north of that 14% for the whole year. Because of that seasonal -- additional seasonality that has been built in with this change of business model.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to get for the model. If you could give us a sense of what percent deferred revenue relates to IB versus other. And then on your comments around the launch of preferred pricing for loyalty programs in some of the larger chain hotels, is there either through meta or through Instant Book, a model where you could see yourself participating in those priority pricing programs?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first question. We have not broken out the relative impact of IB and other. However, if you look at businesses where we have been booking stay [indiscernible] consumption for a longer time like attractions, for instance. Attractions doesn't
componenttext: I'll take the first question. We have not broken out the relative impact of IB and other. However, if you look at businesses where we have been booking stay [indiscernible] consumption for a longer time like attractions, for instance. Attractions doesn't have a big impact on that growth on the growth rate impact, but it's a really localized to Instant Booking and Vacation Rentals. But we don't want to give any further breakdown beyond that.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Steve. With respect to pricing initiatives and some of the big hotel chains have put on with kind of special rates, we can absolutely see a case in point or an example set where those brands choose to push their special pricing on to the TripA
componenttext: And this is Steve. With respect to pricing initiatives and some of the big hotel chains have put on with kind of special rates, we can absolutely see a case in point or an example set where those brands choose to push their special pricing on to the TripAdvisor meta and/or IP platforms such that they want the exposure of some great rates. And our perspective is, if it's a rates that's available to travelers, then we're happy to show it. So our model sort of encourages travelers to find the absolute -- I mean if you wind it all the way back, folks are coming to TripAdvisor because they love the site, the offers, the great user experience, the full trip. They have more content, more choice. Pricing is a key component of that. They find the things, the places they want to stay and the things that they want to do. They make the bookings on TripAdvisor if the price is great, and brands play into that. They're giving us their best pricing. They find what they want to do. They book those pieces on TripAdvisor to have the great trip, to share the experience back on TripAdvisor, therefore, become more engaged with our site and, again, more likely to share their experience with their friends about how TripAdvisor helped them and start their very next bit of travel planning with us. Having the price from the brands is -- or the best price from all components is one of the many things that we need to do right in order to earn that virtuous cycle.

componenttext: Great. Well, thanks, everyone for joining the call. The first quarter 2016 was pivotal for TripAdvisor. We still have a lot of work ahead of us, but we're making great strides towards our goal of building that best user experience in travel. I want to thank our employees around the globe for their continued hard work, and we look forward to updating you on our progress next quarter. Thanks again.
