componenttext: Go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. I guess my question was more around as you develop more of an internal retargeting product, can that potentially ease some of the reliance on some of the third-party ad tech platform you use?
componenttext: I'm sorry. I guess my question was more around as you develop more of an internal retargeting product, can that potentially ease some of the reliance on some of the third-party ad tech platform you use?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The third-party ad tech platforms that we use to acquire traffic to TripAdvisor?
componenttext: The third-party ad tech platforms that we use to acquire traffic to TripAdvisor?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, such as Criteo.
componenttext: Yes, such as Criteo.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't -- the platform that we have developed is for our clients to use rebuying or remarketing to the traffic that was on their site and is now on TripAdvisor. Criteo or anyone else, they can't do that. They can't offer that. That's somethin
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't -- the platform that we have developed is for our clients to use rebuying or remarketing to the traffic that was on their site and is now on TripAdvisor. Criteo or anyone else, they can't do that. They can't offer that. That's something that we had to offer ourselves. And then since we buy traffic elsewhere on the web, we're not trying to get into the business that Criteo is in by way of a broad ad tech platform. We have a huge audience. We will offer to our CPM clients the ability to buy -- to spend on TripAdvisor and buy a banner ad for Hilton, for instance, that is placed on TripAdvisor and is also placed on a third-party site to a visitor that was on TripAdvisor. So we do offer that. It's a growing part of our business. It's a nice part of our business. It doesn't really affect our reliance on other ad tech platforms one way or the other.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a couple of quick ones. In terms of building out the content with respect to IB, attractions or Vacation Rentals or any one of your kind of channels, to what extent is that both a joint exercise on your part but also in conjunction with your partner
componenttext:
Maybe a couple of quick ones. In terms of building out the content with respect to IB, attractions or Vacation Rentals or any one of your kind of channels, to what extent is that both a joint exercise on your part but also in conjunction with your partners? 
And then 2 quick ones. Can you remind us what the exclusivity concerns are around Booking.com and their IB relationship? When do those expire? 
And then as you embark in Phase 3 of your IB road map, how long do you envision that phase kind of playing out?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm not sure I quite followed on the partnership piece. When we kind of add content, the room descriptions, room tips, we're doing that ourselves. If the content you're referring to is more pricing and more availability of rooms, well, that's our su
componenttext: Sure. I'm not sure I quite followed on the partnership piece. When we kind of add content, the room descriptions, room tips, we're doing that ourselves. If the content you're referring to is more pricing and more availability of rooms, well, that's our supply footprint for hotels or attractions or restaurants. And we have our teams going out and getting more and more supply. With that supply comes just more choice in rooms and tours and attractions. So with our partners, well, you can ask a follow-up if I'm missing the point on that one, we don't really comment on partner contracts with respect to things like the Booking.com contract. You've seen more and more suppliers be added to our Instant Book offering over time, and we continue to add partners every single quarter. So we have a lot of flexibility to deliver the product that we want to our customers. Was there something in the partner contracts I missed?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Then the last one, Steve, was just, as you embark on Phase 3, have you talked about how long you envision Phase 3 playing out?
componenttext: No. Then the last one, Steve, was just, as you embark on Phase 3, have you talked about how long you envision Phase 3 playing out?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The phases are meant kind of as guideposts. We're certainly already doing a little bit of Phase 4 right now because we're trying to get people to do more and more repeat bookings. That's great. We've been improving the experience, educating folks, which i
componenttext: The phases are meant kind of as guideposts. We're certainly already doing a little bit of Phase 4 right now because we're trying to get people to do more and more repeat bookings. That's great. We've been improving the experience, educating folks, which is Phase 3. We were starting that in Phase 2. So they're fuzzy, but we've articulated them because, hey, everyone had seen IB in the U.S., but we wanted to remind everyone the clock is just now starting to run on the rest of the major countries throughout the world. That's great. And this phase coming forward is less about intro, less about rollout and now about honing that user experience and driving the behavior that we want. I -- certainly, I -- if you want to combine 3 and 4, the phases last forever. If you want to split them out, Phase 3 will be a while.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dan Wasiolek of Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question is from Dan Wasiolek of Morningstar.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the non-hotel segment, considering the shift to transaction and vacation rental, when we think about the progression of revenue growth for the rest of '16 into '17, should it be something similar to the commentary that you've given on the hotel side
componenttext: So in the non-hotel segment, considering the shift to transaction and vacation rental, when we think about the progression of revenue growth for the rest of '16 into '17, should it be something similar to the commentary that you've given on the hotel side?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Dan, thanks for asking that question. We made the comment in the prepared remarks about our Vacation Rental business. What we outlined is, and this is happening both Instant Booking and in Vacation Rental, is as we move our business models, and we've
componenttext: Yes. Dan, thanks for asking that question. We made the comment in the prepared remarks about our Vacation Rental business. What we outlined is, and this is happening both Instant Booking and in Vacation Rental, is as we move our business models, and we've talked about it in Instant Booking, but if you look at Vacation Rentals, we're moving our business model in Vacation Rental. We have progressively over the last year. So if you look at Q1 2015, we had a small portion of the revenues recognized on stay and other elements of revenue but recognized on book or on subscription. And as we migrate it over the year, now we're in Q1 '16, we see the substantial portion of our revenues is recognized on stay. So that has a significant impact, particularly on the seasonality of our business. Q1 is a quarter in Vacation Rentals in which there are a lot of bookings for later in the year for Q2, but specifically for the summer in Q3. And so what you see, if you compare the year-on-year growth rates, is what you see is that the total of 14% year-on-year growth for non-hotel, which is not just Vacation Rentals, obviously, is suppressed by that impact. And as we look at outlook for the full year, we believe the growth rate for non-hotel will be significantly north of that 14% for the whole year because of that seasonal -- additional seasonality that has been built in with this change of business model.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And the next question is from Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just wanted to get -- for the model, if you could give us a sense of what percent deferred revenue relates to IB versus other. And then on your comments around the launch of preferred pricing for loyalty programs in some of the larger chain hotel
componenttext:
Great. Just wanted to get -- for the model, if you could give us a sense of what percent deferred revenue relates to IB versus other. 
And then on your comments around the launch of preferred pricing for loyalty programs in some of the larger chain hotels, is there, either through meta or through Instant Book, a model where you could see yourself participating in those priority-pricing programs?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first question. We have not broken out the relative impact of IB and other. It's -- however, if you look at businesses where we have been booking at stay or at consumption for a longer time, like attractions, for instance. Attractions doesn'
componenttext: I'll take the first question. We have not broken out the relative impact of IB and other. It's -- however, if you look at businesses where we have been booking at stay or at consumption for a longer time, like attractions, for instance. Attractions doesn't have a big impact on that growth rate impact, but it's really localized to Instant Booking and Vacation Rentals. But we don't want to give any further breakdown beyond that.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Steve. With respect to the pricing initiatives that some of the big hotel chains have put on with kind of special rates, we can absolutely see a case in point or an example set where those brands choose to push their special pricing on to the
componenttext: And this is Steve. With respect to the pricing initiatives that some of the big hotel chains have put on with kind of special rates, we can absolutely see a case in point or an example set where those brands choose to push their special pricing on to the TripAdvisor meta or, and/or IP platforms such that they want the exposure of some great rates. And our perspective is, if it's a rate that's available to travelers, then we're happy to show it. So our model sort of encourages travelers to find the absolute -- well I mean, if you wind it all the way back, folks are coming to TripAdvisor because they love the site, the offers, the great user experience, the full trip. They have more content, more choice. Pricing is a key component of that. They find the things -- the places they want to stay and the things that they want to do. They make the bookings on TripAdvisor if the price is great. And brands play into that, they're giving us their best pricing. They find what they want to do. They book those pieces on TripAdvisor to have the great trip, to share the experience back on TripAdvisor to, therefore, become more engaged with our site, and again, more likely to share their experience with their friends about how TripAdvisor helped them and start their very next bit of travel planning with us. Having the price from the brands is -- or the best price from all components is one of the many things that we need to do right in order to earn that virtuous cycle.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And at this time, I'll turn the call back over to Steve Kaufer for closing remarks.
componenttext: And at this time, I'll turn the call back over to Steve Kaufer for closing remarks.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Well, thanks, everyone, for joining the call. The first quarter 2016 was pivotal for TripAdvisor. We still have a lot of work ahead of us, but we're making great strides towards our goal of building that best user experience in travel. I want to th
componenttext: Great. Well, thanks, everyone, for joining the call. The first quarter 2016 was pivotal for TripAdvisor. We still have a lot of work ahead of us, but we're making great strides towards our goal of building that best user experience in travel. I want to thank our employees around the globe for their continued hard work, and we look forward to updating you on our progress next quarter. Thanks again.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect. Good day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect. Good day.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Rela
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Will Lyons. Please go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Esther. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night after market close, we distributed and filed our Q2 earnings release a
componenttext:
Thanks, Esther. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night after market close, we distributed and filed our Q2 earnings release as well as made available our prepared remarks on our Investor Relations website located at ir.tripadvisor.com. In the release, you will find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call. Also, our IR website contains a supplemental financial information document which includes certain non-GAAP financial measures discussed on this call as well as other performance metrics. Instead of reading our prepared remarks on this call, Steve will provide a couple of thoughts and Ernst will follow up as well, and we'll talk about our recent progress and then we'll jump right into Q&A. 
Before we begin I'd like to remind you that this call may contain estimates and other forward-looking statements that represent the company's view as of today, August 4, 2016. TripAdvisor disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Please refer to our earnings release and our filings with the SEC for information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. And with that, I'll pass the call over to Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you've had a chance to read our prepared remarks since we published them -- that we published last night after market closed. I'll summarize by saying that we continue
componenttext: Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you've had a chance to read our prepared remarks since we published them -- that we published last night after market closed. I'll summarize by saying that we continue to grow content and community especially on mobile devices. We're operating the business with a long-term forward-looking view, and we continue to leverage these competitive strengths as we create a stickier end-to-end-user experience throughout all phases of travel planning, booking and trip-taking. We're pleased with the progress that we made in the second quarter with our key initiatives. Instant Booking is now live across the globe, and we continue to improve our booking capabilities not only in hotels but in attractions, restaurants and vacation rentals. Ernst?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and hello, everyone. I'll just add that these initiatives come with visible near-term revenue and profit headwinds as anticipated and also as communicated at the outset of the year. We continue to navigate a dynamic travel landscape, and we
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and hello, everyone. I'll just add that these initiatives come with visible near-term revenue and profit headwinds as anticipated and also as communicated at the outset of the year. We continue to navigate a dynamic travel landscape, and we believe we're on the best path to drive long-term shareholder value. 
With that, we'll open it up for our questions.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple questions. First one is around mobile. You talk about better book rates coming out of mobile and you highlight the first other devices. When you say other devices, is that both desktop and tablets? Sort of clarification there. And then wond
componenttext: I had a couple questions. First one is around mobile. You talk about better book rates coming out of mobile and you highlight the first other devices. When you say other devices, is that both desktop and tablets? Sort of clarification there. And then wondering if there's any dynamic to call out with the sales and relationships and how that's progressing.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first question. Yes, against other devices, that includes desktop and tablet. Mobile is really our best performer in that case.
componenttext: I'll take the first question. Yes, against other devices, that includes desktop and tablet. Mobile is really our best performer in that case.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And thanks, Brian, for the question. The Samsung relationship generated a number of preinstalled many years ago but I wouldn't characterize that as a critical partnership, even back then and certainly not going forward. We appreciate all the installs. We
componenttext: And thanks, Brian, for the question. The Samsung relationship generated a number of preinstalled many years ago but I wouldn't characterize that as a critical partnership, even back then and certainly not going forward. We appreciate all the installs. We have hundreds of millions of them, but that's a small piece of our mobile puzzle.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two if I can. One on desktop shoppers and one on mobile. First, it looked like desktop hotel shopper growth was negative. So wondering if you saw that across markets or maybe certain markets like North America where revenue accelerated. With desktop shopp
componenttext: Two if I can. One on desktop shoppers and one on mobile. First, it looked like desktop hotel shopper growth was negative. So wondering if you saw that across markets or maybe certain markets like North America where revenue accelerated. With desktop shopper holding up okay, any color you can provide on that, or whether this is kind of structural or temporary would be helpful. And then secondly on mobile, you guys call that app hotel shoppers and revenue both growing at a strong 50%, but it seems like that would imply mobile monetization which has been improving a lot that didn't grow much this quarter in terms of revenue per shopper in app. So wondering if we're interpreting that correctly. And can you kind of walk us through what may have slowed the progress there and how you think it can reverse out?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Lloyd. In terms of number of shoppers and the geo split in that, we've seen weakness in -- across the world in all markets especially we called out sort of into the back half of the quarter, we've seen -- we've not seen the usual holiday s
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Lloyd. In terms of number of shoppers and the geo split in that, we've seen weakness in -- across the world in all markets especially we called out sort of into the back half of the quarter, we've seen -- we've not seen the usual holiday spike or summer spike that we would have seen, and that was across geographies. Having said that, especially earlier on the quarter in -- outside of the United States in all those markets where we rolled out Instant Booking, we perhaps saw a larger impact that is in part driven by the fact that we can spend less as we saw the impact of Instant Booking, but hotel shopping is not completely isolated to outside the U.S. Your second question on mobile monetization, we did see a year-on-year improvement of revenue per shopper in mobile. Mobile revenue grew at about 30%. Our shopper count was up a little over 20%, 23% [ph] in mobile. So that implies an improved monetization for the mobile.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe 2 questions around the sales and marketing efforts of the company. Just want to understand a little bit better on ROI and what you might be seeing or how you can help us understand some of the discounting or incentives you put in place in the letter
componenttext: Maybe 2 questions around the sales and marketing efforts of the company. Just want to understand a little bit better on ROI and what you might be seeing or how you can help us understand some of the discounting or incentives you put in place in the letter commentary you sort of laid out that shift away from TV advertising and sort of moved into those incentives on property to get people to book the first time. Maybe we can understand a little bit how that's progressing, what kind of returns you're getting and what it might mean for how you spend on the sales and marketing plan on the back part of the year.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks for the question. This is Steve. We certainly have been trying a number of different promotions, anything from sweepstakes to an Amazon gift card to a discount on an attraction once you book the hotel. They're all just different ways that we'
componenttext: Sure. Thanks for the question. This is Steve. We certainly have been trying a number of different promotions, anything from sweepstakes to an Amazon gift card to a discount on an attraction once you book the hotel. They're all just different ways that we're both driving home. TripAdvisor is a place that you can now book a hotel, not just read the reviews. So to be clear, part of that kind of promotional goal is really building the brand around this is a place you can book, and part of it certainly serves to drive that first-time booker or second-time booker into the flow because we have our evidence that says, once we get someone to book once, the more likely they come back and book again. And if we can get them to book once or book twice on the app, for instance, it becomes an even stronger habit, and that's what we're looking to build over time. If you figure out the set of users, the large set of users that already trust us for our reviews and push them into the -- trusting us for that booking experience. So we have great scores when we measure how people feel about the booking experience once they've gone through it. So the promotions are taking some of the dollars that we have spent in TV. We feel, as I've said before, that leveraging the vast amount of traffic we have globally that's already on our site is simply a more efficient way for us to get our message out there than some of the other offline activities. It doesn't really tell you much on -- I'm not really able to tell you much on the relative spend for those type of programs in the back half of the year other than to point out what I think is fairly straightforward. Those aren't anywhere near the materiality of the TV spend even though in like ways we were doing it last year.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Perry Gold with Moffat Nathanson.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Perry Gold with Moffat Nathanson.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you provide an update on where you are in terms of conversion rates for Instant Booking versus metasearch maybe by geography or device and how we should be thinking about that pace of improvement? Is that 20% uplift in the desktop in the U.S. for IB l
componenttext: Can you provide an update on where you are in terms of conversion rates for Instant Booking versus metasearch maybe by geography or device and how we should be thinking about that pace of improvement? Is that 20% uplift in the desktop in the U.S. for IB likely to be representative in terms of the pace of growth for IB conversion on mobile or maybe in other regions?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we said before, and this is still the case, that conversion rates in the U.S. have been converging and are similar to the conversion rates in meta. We've seen very good results there. We see continued evidence of the monetization gap narrowing. Outsi
componenttext: Yes, we said before, and this is still the case, that conversion rates in the U.S. have been converging and are similar to the conversion rates in meta. We've seen very good results there. We see continued evidence of the monetization gap narrowing. Outside of the U.S. in all those markets they'll be launched in the second quarter. We've seen, as expected, what we saw early on in the United States as well, that the conversion rates are lower, that there's a much larger gap compared to the U.S., and we believe there is a lot of low-hanging fruit that we have to improve those conversion rates over time and, like in the U.S., hopefully, ultimately see conversion rates that are more similar.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. The standard start of test and learn that we're doing we know will drive improved conversion rates over time in each of our markets. We also get the benefit of the repeat bookers coming back, and those folks, obviously, have been around the
componenttext: This is Steve. The standard start of test and learn that we're doing we know will drive improved conversion rates over time in each of our markets. We also get the benefit of the repeat bookers coming back, and those folks, obviously, have been around the longest in the U.S. so they have a higher conversion rate and haven't been around as much in some of our newer markets. So we'll see the overall conversion rate for IB climb in our newer markets over time anyways because we're simply pulling back people that have already tried it and already like it. On the app is where we continue to be most excited because that's the best spot to build the habit. And when we look at building a habit for someone that travels once maybe twice a year, it's just less interesting to us than the more frequent traveler who can now, with the stored credit card on the app, open up the app, make the booking go, and it's really simple. It's really easy. We have tremendous coverage in most markets, and that kind of habit enables that device and it enables that value proposition to continue to grow for us. And so we'd expect to see continued, on average, conversion improvements because, frankly, we're attracting our repeat visitors more and more often, but that does take quarters and years to build.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You had a significant uptick in a number of bookable products and Viator. And at this point, how would you describe impact on monetization from that uptick in bookability versus just being a resource for information on tourism attractions with limited abi
componenttext: You had a significant uptick in a number of bookable products and Viator. And at this point, how would you describe impact on monetization from that uptick in bookability versus just being a resource for information on tourism attractions with limited ability to monetize? Then I guess what's the reaction from 200 attraction partners to Instant Book? I think it would be positive given they may be less concerned than hotels about retaining brand awareness, et cetera.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a great question, Mike. Thank you very much. Viator's been doing this for quite a while, so we picked up a lot of the popular tourism activities over the years, but there's hundreds of thousands more that want to be online may have their own we
componenttext: Sure. It's a great question, Mike. Thank you very much. Viator's been doing this for quite a while, so we picked up a lot of the popular tourism activities over the years, but there's hundreds of thousands more that want to be online may have their own website but haven't yet connected to any platform like ours. And TripAdvisor has over 600,000 things to do and locations. Many of those places sell tickets and would love the ability to have the booking from our end. That's the whole story around the attractions. The second part of your question, I just haven't ever heard of an attraction owner saying no, I don't like the notion of Instant Booking because it takes away from that branded experience because, as you point out, the attraction is much less likely to be a repeat visit than the hotels. So the attraction is much less interested in building that direct loyalty. They want to make sure their attraction is highly rated, highly visible on Trip, easily bookable, best inventory and most available inventory. And our biggest challenge, frankly, is just getting the pipes, all that connectivity working for as many attractions as we can and then back to the consumer side on TripAdvisor, teaching folks that not only can they figure out the things that they want to do, they can book it, they can book it on desktop. And more importantly, in our long-term view, they can book it on their phone when they are in market, and that's that whole Instant Booking attraction picture.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck with SunTrust.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions please. One, when we look at click-based revenue, it decelerated slightly to I think down about 15%. And last quarter, you were helpful breaking out some of the headwinds that you so, whether it be seasonality, macro or the Instant Boo
componenttext: Two quick questions please. One, when we look at click-based revenue, it decelerated slightly to I think down about 15%. And last quarter, you were helpful breaking out some of the headwinds that you so, whether it be seasonality, macro or the Instant Book transition. I think you can maybe go through and help break out what you saw that in those components. And then, Ernst, as we think about 2017 a could be more of a more normalized growth rate on the top line or stabilized margins can be helpful as well.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our revenue per shopper, the story is somewhat similar as in the previous quarter. So the largest impact on the year-on-year decrease of revenue per shopper is the Instant Booking dilution. We have obviously now been in market outside of the U.S., U.K.
componenttext: So our revenue per shopper, the story is somewhat similar as in the previous quarter. So the largest impact on the year-on-year decrease of revenue per shopper is the Instant Booking dilution. We have obviously now been in market outside of the U.S., U.K. where we were before in a complete 3 months in the second quarter, and that has made a significant impact. That's both, as a reminder, a booked revenue issue as well as rev rec issue in Instant Booking, and so that's a large one. The second in revenue per shopper is the shift to mobile, and we've seen a faster shift in mobile than we anticipated in the second quarter, and this continues to be a drag on the aggregated revenue per shopper number. As we said before, revenue per shopper of mobile is increasing, but it's substantially lower than on desktop and, therefore, with mix shift a reduction of the overall. We've also in the second quarter had tougher meta comps compared to a year ago. We called that out earlier. That's a front half issue that will abate, that will ease in the second part of the quarter. We've also called out that we did see some softness, particularly in June and into July, which we think might be impacted by the macro environment, by the various events that we've seen around the world, be it terror-related or economic events like Brexit, and we believe that has made an impact on us as well on the volume side, on the number of shoppers side and, perhaps, also the revenue per shopper side. Your second part of your question about 2017, in February, we made some statements painting a picture for the shape of '16 but also into '17. We have no reason to update that today, but I also don't want to put a finer point to that. The teams here internally will start to shift over the next months in more detail planning for 2017, and when the time is right, we will provide you some appropriate comments about 2017.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Naved Kahn with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Naved Kahn with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. Steve, maybe you can give us some more color on the shopper growth and how it was impacted by the [indiscernible] on the variable [ph] advertising channel. It looks like you're spending more on promotions related to Instant Boo
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Steve, maybe you can give us some more color on the shopper growth and how it was impacted by the [indiscernible] on the variable [ph] advertising channel. It looks like you're spending more on promotions related to Instant Book. Is that taking away from the spending on traffic acquisition and maybe even hurting the metasearch?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Naved. I'll try and answer. The basic variable marketing channels that we've traditionally used, the center ones, continue apace. No fundamental change in how we approach them. With the rev per shopper decline, that impacts -- based upon our more ne
componenttext: Sure, Naved. I'll try and answer. The basic variable marketing channels that we've traditionally used, the center ones, continue apace. No fundamental change in how we approach them. With the rev per shopper decline, that impacts -- based upon our more neutral approach to those channels, it impacts how much we're able to bid in those channels. So you've seen, we believe, partial decline in hotel shopper growth because of our lower ability to spend in those channels. I wouldn't call out the promotions as -- well, I'm telling you the promotions are not coming at the expense of the variable marketing channels. They are marketing dollars that we are choosing to spend to build up the brand of TripAdvisor as a trusted place to book, but I would caution you against thinking of it, as I mentioned before, in the same magnitude as TV because it's not.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just a follow-up. Can you just talk about the dynamic for the meta auction in the second quarter? Was there any impact from Expedia underindexing in the channel? They talked about that on their earnings call.
componenttext: Understood. And then just a follow-up. Can you just talk about the dynamic for the meta auction in the second quarter? Was there any impact from Expedia underindexing in the channel? They talked about that on their earnings call.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We [indiscernible] for that, and from our seat, we're kind of used to various partners, big ones and small ones, having small to medium changes in how they act quarter on quarter on quarter. So Expedia may have been talking about a little bit differe
componenttext: Yes. We [indiscernible] for that, and from our seat, we're kind of used to various partners, big ones and small ones, having small to medium changes in how they act quarter on quarter on quarter. So Expedia may have been talking about a little bit different approach or different stuff this quarter. We see it but other partners also change their [indiscernible] bids from time to time. I wouldn't view it as the most relevant thing in our overall model. Pricing overall impacts our CPC auction. We continue to make revenue optimization headwinds and we look at the macro issues impacting online travel as another aspect that can both get revenue per shopper as well as total shoppers coming in the store.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your prepared remarks, I think, Ernst, you said that you're now live in substantively all your major markets. Wondering if you could help us understand when kind of from a timing perspective, you might be experiencing maximum IB transition headwinds an
componenttext: In your prepared remarks, I think, Ernst, you said that you're now live in substantively all your major markets. Wondering if you could help us understand when kind of from a timing perspective, you might be experiencing maximum IB transition headwinds and when that curve might start improving?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of rollout, as we said, this second quarter was really the quarter that we had the full 3-month impact of the IB rollout globally. As we've said, over time, we've made improvements in the United States, but this is really the initial rollout o
componenttext: So in terms of rollout, as we said, this second quarter was really the quarter that we had the full 3-month impact of the IB rollout globally. As we've said, over time, we've made improvements in the United States, but this is really the initial rollout outside of the U.S. and the U.K. and the full impact of that. We believe that as we go forward, as we enter in this phase 3 and phase 4 that we were describing our prepared remarks, we, hopefully, should be able to make improvements to our offering and improve our conversion rates over time.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could one more, do you think IB conversion rates could ever exceed meta?
componenttext: Great. And if I could one more, do you think IB conversion rates could ever exceed meta?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. I certainly do believe that IB rates can and sometimes do exceed meta. IT very much depends on the property of the type of traveler. I'll give you a very simple case in point. If a user is looking for a relatively straightforward stay, low
componenttext: This is Steve. I certainly do believe that IB rates can and sometimes do exceed meta. IT very much depends on the property of the type of traveler. I'll give you a very simple case in point. If a user is looking for a relatively straightforward stay, low research intent [ph] vacation, staying 3 nights in the Best Western, conversion rates are really quite high and, as we can tell, higher than the downstream meta. It kind of makes sense. It's a simple transaction, TripAdvisor giving you plenty of information and there's not a big reason to shop around. But we stay in Cancun, where you're looking for a lot more information and sometimes information that, frankly, TripAdvisor doesn't quite have in the form that you're looking for, then Instant Booking is not converting as well as meta. So I certainly understand your question. And when we think over time, yes, we do believe Instant Booking can and should always be able to be better, if our pricing is good, than a meta click. And when we look, on average, we seen the U.S. app, we're already there. But again, the on average already better than meta is a great statement. I still drill it down to different segments of properties and different segments of trips because we want to make sure it's not on average rate. It's great in every different situation that we come across.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I just want to go back to North America and the revenue growth there accelerated a little bit in 2Q. Just wanted to understand the acceleration vector and then just, in particular, how much is that lapping some of these Instant Book impact versus s
componenttext: First, I just want to go back to North America and the revenue growth there accelerated a little bit in 2Q. Just wanted to understand the acceleration vector and then just, in particular, how much is that lapping some of these Instant Book impact versus some of the conversion improvements in the areas where you're doing better? And then secondly can you just talk a little bit about your strategy for determining when you're showing Instant Book and kind of when you're moving it up and down the cage kind of serve the booking process.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that question. So the geo split that you see, the first thing to point out is the mix across our entire business. So it includes TripAdvisor, auction revenue, but it also includes, obviously, other hotel brands as well as attra
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that question. So the geo split that you see, the first thing to point out is the mix across our entire business. So it includes TripAdvisor, auction revenue, but it also includes, obviously, other hotel brands as well as attractions, Vacation Rentals, et cetera. But having said that, across the board and also in our TripAdvisor core, our revenue performance in the U.S. has been better than outside the U.S. for a number of reasons, most importantly, that we are parking much further along in driving improvements in our Instant Booking offering. We've seen lapping of the things that we did last year and we've seen significant improvements we made in conversion in the United States. So we're very pleased with that and we see very good performance there. If you compare that to EMEA breakout at APAC and LATAM, you seeing that the trends are different they are. That is a function of the rollout that we have just done, and you also see in addition to that particularly in a LATAM and APAC, we've seen the weakness. So if you were to ask us where in the portfolio have you seen strong performance and that's strong performance in the second quarter or on a year-on-year basis, clearly, the U.S., stronger performer; and mobile, a stronger performer; and outside the U.S., Europe, weaker and outside of Europe, LATAM and APAC weaker.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Steve. You are wise to point out that change in the IB Instant Book presentation in the website, as internally we call it sort of flexing the interface, to show Instant Book where we think it's truly the best offering for the consumer and not
componenttext: And this is Steve. You are wise to point out that change in the IB Instant Book presentation in the website, as internally we call it sort of flexing the interface, to show Instant Book where we think it's truly the best offering for the consumer and not fully deprecating but lowering its visibility when we don't think that's going to make for a successful experience. We were, perhaps, a little too ambitious when we rolled it out originally putting IB top, front and center no matter what the price was in IB and no matter how appropriate IB was for what the user was looking for, looking back to that example of the Best Western purchase versus the week in Cancun. Now when you look at our site, again, depending on the market, you'll see Instant Book position as a terrific option if it's the right property and the right price, and you'll actually see it float in a different spot depending possibly on whether you've booked on TripAdvisor before. So the team did a terrific job helping to figure out when Instant Book is likely to be successful and when meta is actually a better offering or a better choice for that traveler at that point in time. The user and the traveler, as they go through their journey, in fact, sometimes is more interested in a meta click-off or looking at more information and sometimes more interested in just finishing the booking right there because the price is the same and the purchase path is simple. I would suggest that if you care to continue to look at the site because we expect to continue to look and optimize where and when you see Instant Booking, again, for our mission, helping that traveler plan and book the perfect trip, what are the right times when we're going to see it. The really nice thing, and then my point, is that as we have flex user interface to show meta or IB at the right time, we've increased our revenue and we have not had a meaningful drop in our Instant Bookings because, fundamentally, we're lowering its visibility in cases where we weren't converting anyone anyways. So in this case, the team, again, nice job because we're getting our revenue back, which helps our traffic acquisition and our overall top line, and we're not losing on the Instant Book trial piece, which furthers our building a habit using Instant Book strategy.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Merwin with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Merwin with Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of questions. So first, I think the commentary saw kind of an upward shape in the revenue curve in the back half of the year. Is that going to be mainly driven by revenue per hotel shopper or also pick-up in hotel shoppers as well? And
componenttext: I just had a couple of questions. So first, I think the commentary saw kind of an upward shape in the revenue curve in the back half of the year. Is that going to be mainly driven by revenue per hotel shopper or also pick-up in hotel shoppers as well? And then just the second question, I think really sometimes the difference in price between Instant Book and meta, and can you just remind us I guess how that works and to what extent like a lower price on Instant Book is helping conversion?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and as you all know, we don't provide a formal guidance but we have made the comments that -- a few comments. One is we see our comps easing in the second half, this is the comps from the IB rollout but also from the meta comps that we have highlight
componenttext: Yes, and as you all know, we don't provide a formal guidance but we have made the comments that -- a few comments. One is we see our comps easing in the second half, this is the comps from the IB rollout but also from the meta comps that we have highlighted before. We're also commenting, though, that there are recent software [ph] trends that we have highlighted and they make us more cautious as we look at the rest of the year.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then to answer the first question, the Instant Book price is, generally speaking, the best price that we get from all of our Instant Booking partners, which is frequently the hotel itself, chain or independent, and then likely one or the -- one or mor
componenttext: And then to answer the first question, the Instant Book price is, generally speaking, the best price that we get from all of our Instant Booking partners, which is frequently the hotel itself, chain or independent, and then likely one or the -- one or more of the Priceline companies and perhaps another different OTA. Many times that Instant Book price is not actually the best price in our meta auction. And so since travelers the world over care of most or care hugely about price, when our Instant Book price is not the best price, we're generally not featuring it at the top of the page because we know it's not what users are going to want the most. Our goal is to continue to sign up independent hotels, chains, online travel agencies, resellers, every possible partner who's able to take the booking for a hotel so that when you come to TripAdvisor and use the Instant Book product, you will see TripAdvisor having as good a price as any of our meta partners and, frankly, as anyone across the web has. And so we measure getting technically here, we measure the [indiscernible] ratio of how our Instant Book price compares to our own meta auction to know how many times a smart traveler should be picking Instant Book option because it is equal to the best price in the meta auction.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tom White with Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom White with Macquarie Capital.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you just touched on kind of ramping hotel supply both the kind of independents and chains as well as OTAs. Can you maybe give us a sense of how many direct hotel relationships or contracts you guys have and maybe how quickly that's growing? And the
componenttext: Steve, you just touched on kind of ramping hotel supply both the kind of independents and chains as well as OTAs. Can you maybe give us a sense of how many direct hotel relationships or contracts you guys have and maybe how quickly that's growing? And then just secondly, on conversion rate, there's some discussion of conversion rates for IB versus meta. I guess I'm curious to know whether there's a meaningful difference in conversion rate for IB when kind of that connectivity or the booking is processed by an independent versus one of the large OTAs like meta booking.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, 2 good questions. We're not at a point to release total supply and direct supply numbers. I think we've talked about having the vast majority of the chains on board and we have quite a few independent properties. One of the nice points of that ind
componenttext: Thanks, 2 good questions. We're not at a point to release total supply and direct supply numbers. I think we've talked about having the vast majority of the chains on board and we have quite a few independent properties. One of the nice points of that independent property piece is that so many of them are hearing about us through their channel partner or aware of us because they're responding to reviews. And so they're actually going through our self-service module to sign up. And if that independent hotel uses an Internet booking engine that we support, and we support well over 100 now, it's pretty easy for that property to come on in, put in their credit card, hit a few buttons and away they go. And then they're able to take direct bookings via TripAdvisor, and again, they like it. Feedback is good. We had the desire, the strongest desire to be as broad as we can with Instant Booking. So our natural focus has been the big chains because they can bring on thousands of properties at once and, of course, the big OTAs and super partnership with the Priceline brand. And so you've seen both not only booking.com but also Priceline and Agoda appear in all auctions, not only in the U.S., but in many more markets as well. And as we expand all of that inventory to that OTA relationship, we're delivering Instant Book to more customers in more languages. So the question of the Instant Book conversion via supplier direct versus an OTA, it's a little hard for us to measure simply because it's kind of apples to oranges. The big chain supply we have tends to be the big names, the high confidence, and in general, those tend to convert quite well, oftentimes better than a good OTA partner, because there is some -- we can tell some brand preference for the supplier direct. It's a little more nuanced when it comes to the individual properties signing up, whether the consumer preference is an OTA versus the independent. I leave you with the generalized statement that if the independent or the supplier direct has excellent content in our system, so good room descriptions, good photos and absolutely have equal pricing, then the supplier is likely to get a higher share of the bookings. When we ask ourselves what matters the most, I want to be very clear, it's price. And so hoteliers who are very good at making sure their own website has the best pricing and that's what's shown on our site, then [indiscernible] of that. Where pricing is variable across different partners, then the hotel itself will lose some of the bookings because consumers prefer the cheapest price, simply put.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked a couple of times about the mobile monetization gap, and I just want to get back to it, ask a couple of basic questions. How big is the gap between mobile and desktop and tablet monetization? What's the trend like? What do you think are the bas
componenttext: You talked a couple of times about the mobile monetization gap, and I just want to get back to it, ask a couple of basic questions. How big is the gap between mobile and desktop and tablet monetization? What's the trend like? What do you think are the basic factors causing that gap? And do you think that, that's just inevitable that long term that, that closes or gets eliminated?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The monetization gap that we currently have, so mobile monetizes roughly at about 30% of...
componenttext: Yes. The monetization gap that we currently have, so mobile monetizes roughly at about 30% of...

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phone.
componenttext: Phone.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes phone, at mobile, not the tablets. The phone monetizes at roughly 30%, 1/3 of desktop, and we've seen that improve over time. It's better today than it was a year ago, and we continue to believe that we're well positioned to continue to make improveme
componenttext: Yes phone, at mobile, not the tablets. The phone monetizes at roughly 30%, 1/3 of desktop, and we've seen that improve over time. It's better today than it was a year ago, and we continue to believe that we're well positioned to continue to make improvements and we lead with our mobile product. So as we think into the future, we do anticipate that we see further conversions of the monetization of the phone and desktop. Where that will exactly land is a little difficult to predict at this point.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'd caution folks that sometimes, when you hear us and others talk about mobile, it includes tablet, we try to be clear when we talk about our phone monetization being 1/3 because tablet, for us, looks pretty close to desktop.
componenttext: And I'd caution folks that sometimes, when you hear us and others talk about mobile, it includes tablet, we try to be clear when we talk about our phone monetization being 1/3 because tablet, for us, looks pretty close to desktop.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But qualitatively, can you talk to the factors that are going to cause that gap to narrow over time?
componenttext: But qualitatively, can you talk to the factors that are going to cause that gap to narrow over time?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think -- this is Steve. Absolutely the biggest factor is the consumer building a habit and the expectations of being able to book with us on the app. So there's the macro, and I think almost every travel company at least will talk about how the ph
componenttext: Sure. I think -- this is Steve. Absolutely the biggest factor is the consumer building a habit and the expectations of being able to book with us on the app. So there's the macro, and I think almost every travel company at least will talk about how the phone bookings monetize less per booking than desktop because the phone is still used, in my opinion, for the lower decision support purchases. It's the easier hotel, it's the one night, it's you know what you want, there's less research involved and the heavier more expensive purchases are happening, the less commoditized purchases are still happening more on the desktop. As users convert grow on the phone, as phone apps get even better, that will lessen in the average price of what is booked on the phone will come closer to desktop. Average price is a good proxy for average amount that any less make on those bookings. For us, the habit of booking and rebooking and rebooking on the phone, on the apps specifically, is going to be what we believe drives our future monetization model. We are in -- we kind of the have the best of the many worlds because we have this awesome meta price comparison engine on any device that allows the traveler to make sure they're getting the best deal and we've moved into the transaction business so that they don't have to go anywhere else to get that best deal. They can book on TripAdvisor. If you believe, as we do, that it's going to be an app world -- to many, it's already an app world, to Facebook, it's already an app world, but in that sort of travel purchase, it's moving in that direction, our app being able to help people find what they're looking for, make sure they're getting the best price, click-off in their meta models, they're not getting the best price, use their stored credit card to easily book when we do have the best price so that they made the travel research, they made the travel purchase, now they're taking TripAdvisor on the road with them in that single app to deliver that next experience of what I'm going to do when I get there, how am I going to -- where am I going to eat, how can I make those reservations. And that app world means by overall revenue per shopper, a, gets amortized overall the different stuff we sell, not just hotels; and b, building that habit because we've earned that spot on your phone makes that monetization because of the repeat usage that much better over time. And it's a true that on TripAdvisor desktop, we've been phenomenally blessed with so much traffic, so much trust, so much awareness around the globe. But the desktop website isn't that sticky. It's been our challenge to get people who do the price comparison on Trip, who read the reviews on Trip to not immediately pop over and book somewhere else such that we've completely lost the credit, and that's not a complaint against any of our partners that we deserve all that credit. We're trying as hard as they are to correctly attribute the credit to us. On the app with Instant Booking, we don't have the challenge anymore because we built the habit, people come back and finish their booking right on Trip.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nat Schindler with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nat Schindler with Bank of America.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at your revenue per hotel shopper was down but -- and you're booking mostly on Instant Book, but wouldn't it be down considerably just from mix shift as desktop shrank from mobile? And how much of that difference would there be?
componenttext: If you look at your revenue per hotel shopper was down but -- and you're booking mostly on Instant Book, but wouldn't it be down considerably just from mix shift as desktop shrank from mobile? And how much of that difference would there be?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're correct. So if you look at the drivers in sort of order of importance, the #1 driver was the Instant Booking impact in the second quarter, consisting both of the booked revenue impact from the lower monetization IB as well as from the revenue
componenttext: Yes, you're correct. So if you look at the drivers in sort of order of importance, the #1 driver was the Instant Booking impact in the second quarter, consisting both of the booked revenue impact from the lower monetization IB as well as from the revenue recognition. The #2 driver indeed was the shift from the desktop to the phone, and we're not sizing the individual impact of all those drivers, but it was a significant impact.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up to that. How much is just on IB? What is the difference in monetization between desktop and mobile?
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up to that. How much is just on IB? What is the difference in monetization between desktop and mobile?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not breaking out that in specifics. We said overall the monetization on the phone is 30%, 1/3 of meta. We're not breaking that down between IB or on the phone or IB on the desktop.
componenttext: We're not breaking out that in specifics. We said overall the monetization on the phone is 30%, 1/3 of meta. We're not breaking that down between IB or on the phone or IB on the desktop.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we like about that phone aspect is we continue to see our best repeat rates on the app. We continue to see the strength of the habit, kind of more people booking 4 and 5x on the phone than mobile or on desktop. And if you look at the app experience v
componenttext: What we like about that phone aspect is we continue to see our best repeat rates on the app. We continue to see the strength of the habit, kind of more people booking 4 and 5x on the phone than mobile or on desktop. And if you look at the app experience versus mobile web or desktop, you see that we're pushing harder on Instant Book as the best and easiest option. When you look at the folks who are logged in already members on the app, huge, huge percentage of people that are clearly identifying themselves as TripAdvisor members and happy to book. Combine that with the constant increase in credit card storage, the constant repeat bookings, and it takes time but we're pretty happy with how that picture's shaping up on the app. We're going to face, to be clear, a continued headwind of the shift over to mobile because even though our mobile monetization rate is growing and the app usage is looking really strong, it's still coming from such a smaller rev per shopper base than desktop, but that's one of the reasons why we launch IB. The whole concept of Instant Book in the first place was to kind of solve this problem so that we'd be in a phenomenally strong position in the app world in a few years.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Kopelman with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Kopelman with Cowen & Company.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask you about the softness in June and July. Can you give us any sense of the relative size of the softness this year when compared to the slowdown in meta auction pricing that you saw in June and July last year?
componenttext: I want to ask you about the softness in June and July. Can you give us any sense of the relative size of the softness this year when compared to the slowdown in meta auction pricing that you saw in June and July last year?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't want to put a finer point on it than we've already done. We did see, as we called out, a softness really into June more than in April and May in the particular quarter, and we've seen that softness continue into July. And as I said before, us
componenttext: Yes. I don't want to put a finer point on it than we've already done. We did see, as we called out, a softness really into June more than in April and May in the particular quarter, and we've seen that softness continue into July. And as I said before, usually, we see a very significant spike in June and July that is seasonal. We've seen that much to a lesser extent this year. We've talked about what we believe are some of the headwinds that we're looking at. It's difficult to size the total impact of macro. We've seen, obviously, impact -- localized impacts in the particular markets that were impacted and we can size those, to some extent, but we believe there's something larger going on in the travel environment that is harder to quantify. So we've seen that in June, July. When we say, when we look at the rest of the year, that we're more cautious, it is really because it is difficult for us to forecast how much of that June, July weakness is going to persist throughout the end of the year, and that's the reason for our cautiousness.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Steve, 0.5 million bookable hotel properties now. Any way to characterize the number of rooms? And when you are pretty much done getting full adoption of IB, what do you think the bookable property count and the room count will look like?
componenttext: So Steve, 0.5 million bookable hotel properties now. Any way to characterize the number of rooms? And when you are pretty much done getting full adoption of IB, what do you think the bookable property count and the room count will look like?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. So because of the Priceline Group relationship and the fact that we have all of their inventory, I'd say the bookable properties number is huge. It covers just about everything we want because you think of how strong the Priceline Group com
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. So because of the Priceline Group relationship and the fact that we have all of their inventory, I'd say the bookable properties number is huge. It covers just about everything we want because you think of how strong the Priceline Group companies are, covering basically most interesting bookable hotels. We've always looked at our meta auction by hey, as a percentage of page views, how many of the properties that we have do we have a commerce link for, and that number has been quite steady for several years. And I think the number now that we have is 0.5 million bookable properties is going to be pretty steady. Priceline generally has most, if not all, of the rooms at a property, so we don't generally go down to be kind of room level count. But if you think of our inventory as the superset of the Priceline brands plus the Expedia affiliate network brands, via Tingo, plus Get a Room, plus the other suppliers that we signed up, in total bookable properties, I can kind of say, at least in English, I can kind of say, checkmark, that all that matter. I can't say checkmark yet on do we have the best price on all those properties because Priceline is strong as they are on pricing doesn't always have the best price and that's why people generally shop around on the net. They're very, very good at it, but TripAdvisor has the opportunity to be even better because when Priceline has a great price per property, we can take it from them. When the hotel itself has a better price, we can take the person from them and they can both be Instant Book partners. So I wouldn't look at or I don't care much about at this point, the trajectory of bookable properties. I care more about how we're doing by way of content and pricing for those properties and then the expansion into as many link [indiscernible] as we can support.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this time, of showing no further questions. I would like to turn the call back over to Steve Kaufer for any closing remarks.
componenttext: At this time, of showing no further questions. I would like to turn the call back over to Steve Kaufer for any closing remarks.

componenttext: Okay well thanks, everyone for joining the call. I want to thank all of our employees around the globe for their continued hard work. Everyone is doing a great job for us. We appreciate that and we look forward to updating all of you on our progress next quarter. Thanks very much.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
