headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded.At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Rela
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Will Lyons. Please go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chelsea. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO.Last night, after market close, we distributed and filed our Q3 earnings release
componenttext:
Thanks, Chelsea. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO.
Last night, after market close, we distributed and filed our Q3 earnings release as well as made available our prepared remarks on our Investor Relations website located at ir.tripadvisor.com. In the release, you will find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call. Also, our IR website contains a supplemental financial information document, which includes certain non-GAAP financial measures discussed on this call as well as other performance metrics.
Instead of reading our prepared remarks on this call, Steve and Ernst will provide a couple of thoughts about the quarter and about our recent progress, and then we'll jump right into Q&A.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that this call may contain estimates and other forward-looking statements that represent the company's view as of today, November 9, 2016. TripAdvisor disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Please refer to our earnings release and our filings with the SEC for information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements.
And with that, I'll pass the call over to you, Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you have had the chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying that we have continued to make nice prog
componenttext:
Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you have had the chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying that we have continued to make nice progress on our key long-term initiatives. As our core content and community assets continue to grow, we are investing to introduce more users to our full suite of travel products and help travelers unlock more experiences and more moments than any other travel brand.
Ernst?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, total revenue grew 1% year-over-year, and growth rates in hotel and non-hotel segments improved modestly compared to our second quarter results. We're still in the very early days at demonstrati
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, total revenue grew 1% year-over-year, and growth rates in hotel and non-hotel segments improved modestly compared to our second quarter results. We're still in the very early days at demonstrating the financial benefit of plugging the monetization leak. However, we continue to see very nice leading indicators of success. We believe this journey will pay off financially, but it will take time. We're moving fast, we're learning, we're improving, and we believe that we're on the best path to maximize long-term growth and shareholder value creation.
With that, I'd like to open up the call for questions.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe with respect to the commentary in the shareholder letter on investments going forward, so you're starting to lap the impact from the U.S. launch, to lap the impact of the non-U.S. launches through '16 and into '17. But can you help us -- give us som
componenttext: Maybe with respect to the commentary in the shareholder letter on investments going forward, so you're starting to lap the impact from the U.S. launch, to lap the impact of the non-U.S. launches through '16 and into '17. But can you help us -- give us some color on what some of those investments are you think are key [ph] and the scope of those investments so we can better understand where you buy [ph] the best and how it might move the needle for broad adoption of idea in the platform as we move into '17?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. I -- so basically, as we continued to lap over the IB rollout, we now get to see more of the benefit of improved revenue per session as opposed to sort of dealing with the decline. As we continue to make our conversion improvements, that al
componenttext: This is Steve. I -- so basically, as we continued to lap over the IB rollout, we now get to see more of the benefit of improved revenue per session as opposed to sort of dealing with the decline. As we continue to make our conversion improvements, that allows us to invest more in pay traffic acquisition. But frankly, we've also built a better product now, so a lot of the wins that we've had over the past several -- over the past year in terms of conversion flow, in terms of having better pricing in Instant Book, in flexing the interface that we've talked about before, those all come down to enabling our travelers to be able to book better, and that allows us to invest more significantly in pay traffic acquisition. We're developing a better longer-term repeat user model, and we've never been shy about investing for the long term.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first one, you called out some positive comments on Instant Book trends, in particular in September. But when you look at U.S. revenue growth in the third quarter, the oldest market for IB, it looks like it slowed a bit on an easier comp. And
componenttext: I guess the first one, you called out some positive comments on Instant Book trends, in particular in September. But when you look at U.S. revenue growth in the third quarter, the oldest market for IB, it looks like it slowed a bit on an easier comp. And then just kind of sequentially, the revenue per hotel shopper declined from the second quarter to [ph] the third quarter on a sequential basis. So can you talk about some of the puts and takes around what's behind some of those metrics?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Ernst. The -- if you look at our core TripAdvisor auction transaction and auction revenues, the U.S. actually sequentially improved quarter-to-quarter and throughout the quarter, both on revenue and revenue per shopper. And what we thought wa
componenttext: Yes. This is Ernst. The -- if you look at our core TripAdvisor auction transaction and auction revenues, the U.S. actually sequentially improved quarter-to-quarter and throughout the quarter, both on revenue and revenue per shopper. And what we thought was a particularly good sign is now in the third quarter as we cross the point where revenue per shopper and revenue in the U.S. was actually, first, neutral year-on-year and now, in the last months, positive year-on-year. So we thought that was a very good sign because at the end of August, we were lapping the -- a sizable rollout in the U.S. for IB last year, and we feel it's a very good news for us that we see that positive momentum year-on-year. We saw that -- we saw it combined with conversion improvements in the U.S. We saw year-on-year conversion rate improvements on the desktop, IB, on meta. We saw very healthy meta auction dynamics. We saw very healthy IB dynamics. And this gives us a lot of hope that the U.S., now we were lapping the full rollout of IB a year ago, is in increasingly good shape. You can trust that with outside of the U.S. and you see that the growth rates outside of the U.S. are still negative for revenue and revenue per shopper year-on-year as we are not lapping that rollout of IB yet, but we wanted to highlight in our prepared remarks that the U.S. is now in positive territory.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. And a second, if I can, just the prepared remarks imply that even in mobile app, IB is a monetization headwind. So just curious, we would have always thought that it was immediately accretive given poor conversion rates in metasearch and mobile
componenttext: Yes. Okay. And a second, if I can, just the prepared remarks imply that even in mobile app, IB is a monetization headwind. So just curious, we would have always thought that it was immediately accretive given poor conversion rates in metasearch and mobile. So can you maybe give us a little bit more color on the unit [ph] economics of IB in mobile and kind of how that's trending?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This quarter, we made a particular push on the app, and we went to a more dominant display of Instant Booking on the app. And that has had, and [ph] immediate in the quarter, a negative impact. It's not the same as saying what is just [ph] a like-for-like
componenttext: This quarter, we made a particular push on the app, and we went to a more dominant display of Instant Booking on the app. And that has had, and [ph] immediate in the quarter, a negative impact. It's not the same as saying what is just [ph] a like-for-like monetization. We actually quite significantly changed the whole unit -- the UI in the quarter. This had a negative impact in the quarter, but we continue to improve from there. We think that it positions us very well strategically, and we think that with changes over time, we can get that to positive.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Merwin with Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Merwin with Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the letter, I think you alluded to the ongoing strength of meta, and I was wondering if you could just talk a bit more about how you think about the meta business long term relative to IB. I think in the early stages, at one point, there's an invest
componenttext: So in the letter, I think you alluded to the ongoing strength of meta, and I was wondering if you could just talk a bit more about how you think about the meta business long term relative to IB. I think in the early stages, at one point, there's an investor perception, correct or otherwise, that the IB business would at one point fully overtake meta. But just wanted to hear from you if that is still [ph] sort of your long-term vision for Trip and what these 2 products look like when you get to more of a steady state for Instant Book once you kind of lap and complete the full rollout globally.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Chris. This is Steve. I don't think I would've ever said meta -- I mean, IB would overtake meta. We've always believed, I've always maintained, that meta is an integral part of our value proposition. Travelers want to come to our site. They
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Chris. This is Steve. I don't think I would've ever said meta -- I mean, IB would overtake meta. We've always believed, I've always maintained, that meta is an integral part of our value proposition. Travelers want to come to our site. They get the phenomenal content, information, the trust, the community. And then travelers really wanted to know that they're getting the best price, and meta delivers on that best price. And if the client has a brand loyalty to an OTA or to a supplier direct, and they wish to book on that site, we were fine with that because meta enables that. If the user wants to book on TripAdvisor through Instant Book because we have great price and great content, then that would be a straightforward mechanism and arguably easier on the phone because it's less [ph] of a click away. But that when we look at being successful in the eyes of our travelers is, did we help to find the property they wanted and did we help them book it at the best price, book it on TripAdvisor or book it on our partner sites through meta. So meta remains critical. I don't frankly ever foresee it going away, period, full stop. And then the delta is just over the course of the next several years, where do our consumers choose to go. Do they choose to go into the IB flow because pricing and content and why not and they trust TripAdvisor, well that's fine. If they choose to go into the meta flow, we want to help them book, first and foremost. We obviously recognize that if they actually book on TripAdvisor, they're more likely to come back to TripAdvisor. So we have an inherent interest in that as a flow, but it will never commit [ph] at the expense of meta going away, at least I wouldn't predict -- ever predict that.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And operationally, we have teams focused on Instant Booking, but we also have teams focused on improving the metasearch auction. This year -- this quarter, we saw nice trends on CPCs in the meta auction. We see good traction for our remarketing product. W
componenttext: And operationally, we have teams focused on Instant Booking, but we also have teams focused on improving the metasearch auction. This year -- this quarter, we saw nice trends on CPCs in the meta auction. We see good traction for our remarketing product. We have some other products that we're rolling out there. So meta is definitely an area where we continue to invest. It's a large part of our revenue and profits, and we're continuing to be focused on making sure that grows attractively.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck with SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck with SunTrust.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rodney for Bob. Two if I could. As we think about 2017, the company investing again in paid marketing channels to sort of grow the funnel, how fast or how much more do you think the shopper growth can reaccelerate to what sort of levels are you lo
componenttext: This is Rodney for Bob. Two if I could. As we think about 2017, the company investing again in paid marketing channels to sort of grow the funnel, how fast or how much more do you think the shopper growth can reaccelerate to what sort of levels are you looking at? And the second question [ph], you noted in the commentary on the vaulted credit card number. Any sense of what that number has been growing to? That would be helpful.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Hotel shoppers is difficult to forecast for us. There are market and competitive forces at play. We do think that with revenue per shoppers improving into the next year, we will have an opportunity to also spend more. We also believe that spend
componenttext: Thank you. Hotel shoppers is difficult to forecast for us. There are market and competitive forces at play. We do think that with revenue per shoppers improving into the next year, we will have an opportunity to also spend more. We also believe that spending more on marketing may not necessarily only impact hotel shoppers, it may actually help our revenue per shopper as we retarget customers as well. It's very difficult for us to say at this point what exactly the -- our expectation for the impact is, but I do want to underline that we're aiming to affect [ph] both metrics.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think another question on the hotel shopper growth because it does remain at a relatively lower level versus where it has been in the past. So I suppose you can't continue to grow 10%, 15% forever, but the current level suggests that there might
componenttext: Steve, I think another question on the hotel shopper growth because it does remain at a relatively lower level versus where it has been in the past. So I suppose you can't continue to grow 10%, 15% forever, but the current level suggests that there might be some sort of a stressful change. So any details you can offer in terms of what might be happening there, especially as the consumer value proposition, the content that you have on the site remains, in my opinion, same as before. And also, I think you saw Priceline write down some of the goodwill for OpenTable. Just wondering if the competitive environment for LaFourchette internationally has shifted meaningfully for you guys.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm not sure I can add much on the hotel shopper. I do kind of reiterate a point Ernst was making in that on the paid marketing side, when you go out booking for new traffic, you can get a combination of traffic that has not been to your site before
componenttext: Sure. I'm not sure I can add much on the hotel shopper. I do kind of reiterate a point Ernst was making in that on the paid marketing side, when you go out booking for new traffic, you can get a combination of traffic that has not been to your site before, which is an increase in monthly hotel shoppers, or you can get traffic that has been to your site before and you're buying them back in remarketing fashion. Those remarketed shoppers aren't going to increase the total number of monthly hotel shoppers, but they are actually pretty important as we try to plug our leak. So for me, I look at the revenue per shopper and how well we are able to monetize the site a bit more than absolute percentage growth of hotel shoppers. It's just the way I look at it. We certainly -- when we look at the stats and you compare them against the competition, we have a lot of hotel shoppers. And several of the other travel categories are just able to monetize them a lot better than we are. To the second question, Priceline writing down OpenTable, well, we've -- OpenTable is certainly a terrific product, has tremendous market share in a number of the markets in which they operate. We've seen them on the ground in Europe or see their attempts. And so we've known or did that they haven't been much of an impact on our business in our core countries in Europe. So the write-down wasn't informative to us.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you'll see that in our total non-hotel segment, we're showing attractive -- continued attractive year-on-year growth, and restaurants is definitely a positive contributor to that.
componenttext: And you'll see that in our total non-hotel segment, we're showing attractive -- continued attractive year-on-year growth, and restaurants is definitely a positive contributor to that.

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rob on the call for Peter. A follow-up on your comments on the promotion of IB in the app. I think, last quarter, you said click-in [ph] transaction revenue in app grew about 50%. Wondering if you could provide an update for the third quarter. And
componenttext: This is Rob on the call for Peter. A follow-up on your comments on the promotion of IB in the app. I think, last quarter, you said click-in [ph] transaction revenue in app grew about 50%. Wondering if you could provide an update for the third quarter. And then also, just wondering if you could provide some color on how the display business is performing, any update on trends there.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw phone app users grow 50% year-on-year. That was attractive growth for us. We continue to see good traction on the app. We did comment on the monetization in the third quarter as we rolled out Instant Booking, more if you look at the underlying volu
componenttext: We saw phone app users grow 50% year-on-year. That was attractive growth for us. We continue to see good traction on the app. We did comment on the monetization in the third quarter as we rolled out Instant Booking, more if you look at the underlying volume trends. They're very, very positive. Sorry, what was your second question?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just any update you can provide on the performance of the display business, industry trends or anything you're seeing there.
componenttext: Just any update you can provide on the performance of the display business, industry trends or anything you're seeing there.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The display business continues to be a solid part of our hotel business and our total offering that we make to our hotels and on the site. It has continued to grow throughout this year. Not more update to give there at this point.
componenttext: The display business continues to be a solid part of our hotel business and our total offering that we make to our hotels and on the site. It has continued to grow throughout this year. Not more update to give there at this point.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Perry Gold with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Perry Gold with MoffettNathanson.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you please comment on phone monetization relative to desktop tablet this quarter? Can we assume it may have degraded a bit on a relative basis simply because meta was reemphasized in certain cases on the desktop, and IB more aggressively pushed down t
componenttext: Can you please comment on phone monetization relative to desktop tablet this quarter? Can we assume it may have degraded a bit on a relative basis simply because meta was reemphasized in certain cases on the desktop, and IB more aggressively pushed down the app?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it did great this quarter for the reasons that we outlined on the app. It was -- we have commented before that it's about a 30% monetization relative to the desktop. That degraded a little this quarter, but we think longer term, we can continue to na
componenttext: Yes, it did great this quarter for the reasons that we outlined on the app. It was -- we have commented before that it's about a 30% monetization relative to the desktop. That degraded a little this quarter, but we think longer term, we can continue to narrow that gap.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Nat Schindler with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Nat Schindler with Bank of America.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to look at the bases, it's looked like somewhere 50-50, mobile and desktop, as you say. I mean, that is up from, I think, 1/3 last quarter. But what is keeping that [indiscernible] for these numbers? Roughly, a 20% growth in mobile hotel shopper t
componenttext: So just to look at the bases, it's looked like somewhere 50-50, mobile and desktop, as you say. I mean, that is up from, I think, 1/3 last quarter. But what is keeping that [indiscernible] for these numbers? Roughly, a 20% growth in mobile hotel shopper traffic and a near 20% decline in desktop. And if that's the case, so is there any reason to suggest that, that would stop that trend? Do you see this trend continuing?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nat. I think I may have ended up confusing folks a bit more. When I looked at the 50-50, in my mind, I was probably considering desktop versus other. And so when you throw tablet in there, I think we probably are closer to 60-40 in traffic in term
componenttext: Thanks, Nat. I think I may have ended up confusing folks a bit more. When I looked at the 50-50, in my mind, I was probably considering desktop versus other. And so when you throw tablet in there, I think we probably are closer to 60-40 in traffic in terms of desktop plus tablet versus phone.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, if you look at hotel shoppers, that's [ph] total users, hotel shopper is a lower percentage of phone usage. It's closer to 40%, the other way 40-60. But then we talked about the relative monetization. So if you look at it on a revenue basis, yo
componenttext: And again, if you look at hotel shoppers, that's [ph] total users, hotel shopper is a lower percentage of phone usage. It's closer to 40%, the other way 40-60. But then we talked about the relative monetization. So if you look at it on a revenue basis, you can do the multiplications on a revenue basis, the phone is a much smaller percentage.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't think we've seen a meaningful shift in the growth of phone over the past several quarters. So I don't think we're looking at just in terms of adoption from desktop. So we're not calling out any particular change in any trends.
componenttext: So I don't think we've seen a meaningful shift in the growth of phone over the past several quarters. So I don't think we're looking at just in terms of adoption from desktop. So we're not calling out any particular change in any trends.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you would expect in 2017 very similar desktop traffic shrinking at similar rates as mobile traffic growing?
componenttext: So you would expect in 2017 very similar desktop traffic shrinking at similar rates as mobile traffic growing?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little early to be specific about these trends for next year, but the trends that we have been seeing in terms of relative growth of desktop and mobile are likely to continue.
componenttext: It's a little early to be specific about these trends for next year, but the trends that we have been seeing in terms of relative growth of desktop and mobile are likely to continue.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us any more color on your direct advertising cost plan for Q4? It looks like that line was up 5% year-over-year last quarter but about 20% x TV. So how should we think about those as you anniversary TV?
componenttext: Could you give us any more color on your direct advertising cost plan for Q4? It looks like that line was up 5% year-over-year last quarter but about 20% x TV. So how should we think about those as you anniversary TV?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Without giving any specific outlook for the fourth quarter, if you look at the year overall, we've had fairly modest year-on-year increase in our pay traffic spend. As we were indicating in our commentaries about 2017, going into 2017, we may lead in a li
componenttext: Without giving any specific outlook for the fourth quarter, if you look at the year overall, we've had fairly modest year-on-year increase in our pay traffic spend. As we were indicating in our commentaries about 2017, going into 2017, we may lead in a little bit more on pay traffic.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Naved Khan of Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Naved Khan of Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit of clarification on your last answer. Are you also thinking of going back on TV for advertising? And then I couple of follow-ups.
componenttext: Just a little bit of clarification on your last answer. Are you also thinking of going back on TV for advertising? And then I couple of follow-ups.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we stopped on TV about a year ago, we said we would pause in 2016 and then reassess going into 2017. We're still in that phase where we're reassessing so I don't want to make any comments yet but when we're going to come out there. On TV it's on
componenttext: Yes, when we stopped on TV about a year ago, we said we would pause in 2016 and then reassess going into 2017. We're still in that phase where we're reassessing so I don't want to make any comments yet but when we're going to come out there. On TV it's one of the options that we have been considering throughout the year for next year.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I'm just trying to sort of do some -- do my math here and just want to make sure I'm doing it right. If I look at the revenue it looks like last quarter, you did benefit from some of the positive earnings from the prior quarter. How did tha
componenttext: Okay. And then I'm just trying to sort of do some -- do my math here and just want to make sure I'm doing it right. If I look at the revenue it looks like last quarter, you did benefit from some of the positive earnings from the prior quarter. How did that affect the monetization metric if it did?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at revenue recognition and the impact of that, we've been describing that our -- we have a seasonal impact of deferred revenues and it is impacting different parts of our business. If you look at the difference between book revenue and reco
componenttext: So if you look at revenue recognition and the impact of that, we've been describing that our -- we have a seasonal impact of deferred revenues and it is impacting different parts of our business. If you look at the difference between book revenue and recognized revenue across our -- all our businesses for the quarter, it was a year-on-year tailwind of about 2% growth. If you look at currency, that was about a 2% headwind. So those 2 impacts would net each other out for each quarter.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then one last question, maybe Steve, maybe you can answer this, but do you think additional -- another player, when we look at Expedia to Instant Book and further improve the monetization? Or are you at a point where you think that the im
componenttext: Okay, great. And then one last question, maybe Steve, maybe you can answer this, but do you think additional -- another player, when we look at Expedia to Instant Book and further improve the monetization? Or are you at a point where you think that the impact would be very, very marginal?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do believe the more partners that we have globally on the platform enables us to offer -- if the partner has better pricing some of the time, it allows us to offer better pricing to our travelers. When we have better pricing, we have a higher conversion
componenttext: I do believe the more partners that we have globally on the platform enables us to offer -- if the partner has better pricing some of the time, it allows us to offer better pricing to our travelers. When we have better pricing, we have a higher conversion rate. So in that sense, a partner the size of Expedia is likely to have better pricing some of the time, so that would help our conversion rate and, therefore, help us financially.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, relative to a couple of years ago, has anything changed in your view of what Instant Book can do for the company over the long term? Is it just on a different time line perhaps than what you may have originally anticipated? And is there any view yo
componenttext: Steve, relative to a couple of years ago, has anything changed in your view of what Instant Book can do for the company over the long term? Is it just on a different time line perhaps than what you may have originally anticipated? And is there any view you can share on when you think Instant Book in the U.S. can be become revenue-accretive?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a great question. And we've thought about a fair amount internally and we continue to believe pretty passionately that we are on the right path with Instant Book. If you look at our total usage of the TripAdvisor and the site and of course, the ap
componenttext: So it's a great question. And we've thought about a fair amount internally and we continue to believe pretty passionately that we are on the right path with Instant Book. If you look at our total usage of the TripAdvisor and the site and of course, the app, end market, the loyalty and appreciation, the trust we have from our users globally, yet the business model is based upon doing all that -- was based upon doing all that and then sending folks off somewhere else to book. And we were missing all of the easy bookings or all of the opportunity to be the app that someone opens when they're ready to book something. And so with Instant Book, we've addressed that. It's absolutely taken longer than we thought but this a multi, multibillion-dollar opportunity. As we've explained before, as we can close the gap between us and what a typical online travel agency generates in terms of revenue from these travelers, it's such a huge win for us. The thing that's clearly been harder that or if it's taken longer than we thought has been the changing of the consumer perception so that they do or they would open up the app or come right back to the website when they're ready to finally book versus go to where they're familiar with. But as we say, we see the green shoots, we see it happening, and we have projected it would happen sooner. But we still like what we see and we're very comfortable we're on the right path.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to the second part of your question, we believe we're at now breakeven on desktop in the U.S. We've made excellent progress, I described before conversion improvements again this quarter year-on-year on IB. Outside of the U.S. we're still somewhere aw
componenttext: And to the second part of your question, we believe we're at now breakeven on desktop in the U.S. We've made excellent progress, I described before conversion improvements again this quarter year-on-year on IB. Outside of the U.S. we're still somewhere away since we just rolled out earlier in the year. But again, there, we believe over the longer term, we can break even and then make it accretive to the whole business over time.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up, Ernst, when you say you're breakeven, you're saying you're essentially at revenue parity now with what you've moved to Instant Book versus what you're doing before with meta?
componenttext: Just to follow up, Ernst, when you say you're breakeven, you're saying you're essentially at revenue parity now with what you've moved to Instant Book versus what you're doing before with meta?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I say we believe because it's not an entirely scientific way of answering that question, we've made a lot of changes and it's difficult to completely assess what the like-for-like would've been if we hadn't made the changes, but based on all the
componenttext: Yes, and I say we believe because it's not an entirely scientific way of answering that question, we've made a lot of changes and it's difficult to completely assess what the like-for-like would've been if we hadn't made the changes, but based on all the indicators that we do have and that we do have, we believe are currently IB is neutral to the overall economics.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Viator, it looks like online bookable activities is in the single-digit percentages of the 730,000 activities on your sites. What's been the biggest headwind for tour operators not joining online bookable? And are there certain types of activities or t
componenttext: On Viator, it looks like online bookable activities is in the single-digit percentages of the 730,000 activities on your sites. What's been the biggest headwind for tour operators not joining online bookable? And are there certain types of activities or tours that are adopting the online channels faster?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean I don't think there's a single objection. We have an awful lot of attractions. It still takes some effort to onboard each and everyone. And so we go after the ones that we think consumers want to book the most. As I'm sure you're aware, many of the
componenttext: I mean I don't think there's a single objection. We have an awful lot of attractions. It still takes some effort to onboard each and everyone. And so we go after the ones that we think consumers want to book the most. As I'm sure you're aware, many of the attractions are government owned. They don't have an ability for us to do kind of an instant electronic ticketing. So for that, we have to wait for their use of technology to catch up. That will be a while. I don't view our attraction business that was being -- our growth in our attractions business right now to be particularly limited by supply connectivity. Obviously, the more supply we have, the faster we'll grow, but we've done a phenomenally good job of aggregating up supply. And now I think the big challenge is to put it in front of people on a timely basis and, otherwise, get the kinks out of that system.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you get our prepared remarks, we noted that supply grew 70% year-on-year, the number of partners, 60% year-on-year. We continue to believe that it's a great opportunity for us to grow in a very fragmented market.
componenttext: If you get our prepared remarks, we noted that supply grew 70% year-on-year, the number of partners, 60% year-on-year. We continue to believe that it's a great opportunity for us to grow in a very fragmented market.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt with Stifel.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt with Stifel.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's understandable why the user experience and monetization have evolved as your traffic has shifted from desktop to mobile. In terms of just better understanding -- and this is a follow-up on, I suppose, to Doug's question, whether this was done from a
componenttext: It's understandable why the user experience and monetization have evolved as your traffic has shifted from desktop to mobile. In terms of just better understanding -- and this is a follow-up on, I suppose, to Doug's question, whether this was done from a position of strength or weakness, I'm wondering whether you think the business will be better in a mobile environment at some point in time versus desktop in financial terms or if it's possible that the business model was optimized for desktop and then it's proving as you make this transition to be difficult to replicate that monetization.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the switch to mobile, the move to mobile may be a short term headwind for us as we monetize less, but it's something that is almost tailored towards where we're extremely strong, which is in destination marketplace. So I can't quote specific numbe
componenttext: I think the switch to mobile, the move to mobile may be a short term headwind for us as we monetize less, but it's something that is almost tailored towards where we're extremely strong, which is in destination marketplace. So I can't quote specific numbers, I suppose, but we have way more people using the TripAdvisor app when they're on the road. As you look to an app environment, we would suspect people are using fewer sites. And if that app first world comes to be, you'll have to have Trip -- we'd like to think you'll have to have TripAdvisor on your phone because we're the app that's going to be used in the market, so long as you know of us as a place to book, then we're going to earn our fair share of your bookings. So I think as an opportunity, the app is -- over the mobile environment, phone environment, is fantastic. We've been focused to a decent degree on making sure that, that full experience is a solid one, not just the booking piece. And I think that helps differentiate us from the other travel apps you might have on your phone so that we can continue to win the hearts and minds of travelers.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Erickson with Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Erickson with Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just first on Instant Book. Are there any other platform or technology investments broadly that need to be made in order to make Instant Book the destination that you wanted to become in the future? Do you think you're now really equipped in order
componenttext: I guess just first on Instant Book. Are there any other platform or technology investments broadly that need to be made in order to make Instant Book the destination that you wanted to become in the future? Do you think you're now really equipped in order to drive the sort of model transition that you've got mapped out over the next couple of years?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we always have to put the lens of the consumer on when we try to answer that question. And right now I think every time you look at the Instant Book offering and you don't see that it's at least as good a price as where you'd find elsewhere on the
componenttext: I think we always have to put the lens of the consumer on when we try to answer that question. And right now I think every time you look at the Instant Book offering and you don't see that it's at least as good a price as where you'd find elsewhere on the web, when you look at the room descriptions and the photos, and you see that they're not quite as good as what you can find on another site, that's an opportunity for improvement that we have to do in order to win the conversion on that site. And I think if you look at the magical secrets of the other agencies selling hotels on the web, you'll find that attention to detail, making sure the consumer has the best possible price, the best selection of rooms, the content, the photos. And we are, in some part, dependent upon our partners, our OTA and our supplier direct partners for that. So having more partners on board, well implemented, will improve all of those things including rates. And to be clear, our rates have been improving over the past 12 months, and that's part of the reason why you've seen an uptick in conversion. But I think it will -- there's no one big thing we're missing, one big technology investment we're missing, but I think we would forecast out steady improvement in Instant Book because of the additional supply partners that we will continue to add for a long, long time. And I'd say for a long, long time in part because there's hundreds of thousands of them independent hotels out there that want to be on our platform that we would like to have on our platform that we haven't gotten to yet.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then could you just provide the portion of bookings that you're getting from directly linked hotel inventory versus Booking.com?
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then could you just provide the portion of bookings that you're getting from directly linked hotel inventory versus Booking.com?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't give out that percentage, but you do have to appreciate that in order to try to teach users that they can book on TripAdvisor, we wanted to be able to offer the widest selection in as many languages, in as many markets as we can. And booking.com
componenttext: We don't give out that percentage, but you do have to appreciate that in order to try to teach users that they can book on TripAdvisor, we wanted to be able to offer the widest selection in as many languages, in as many markets as we can. And booking.com and Agoda and Priceline brands in general have been really great partners for us on this. And so the percentage of bookings that an independent hotel, even a popular one in the United States, can provide just pales in comparison to what that partnership delivers for us day in day out. So we don't share specifics, but I can tell you the folks with the biggest supply footprint in the most languages are clearly the ones that they get the most bookings.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could give us a sense -- I know you don't generally go into sources of traffic, but if you could -- given the changes that Google has been making, particularly to organic placement, to what degree we should be thinking that headwind
componenttext: Just wondering if you could give us a sense -- I know you don't generally go into sources of traffic, but if you could -- given the changes that Google has been making, particularly to organic placement, to what degree we should be thinking that headwind into account when thinking about hotel shopper growth? And then looking at the Priceline, Expedia, participation, it would seem that the international side seems to be where the gap is widening the most between the 2. How much of that is a function of Instant Book versus maybe some other factor that we're not seeing there?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wouldn't really say there's anything new on the Google organic front, the search results. So it remains a headwind. It's been that way for many, many years now as Google continues to put their kind of owned and operated placements ahead of what users
componenttext: So I wouldn't really say there's anything new on the Google organic front, the search results. So it remains a headwind. It's been that way for many, many years now as Google continues to put their kind of owned and operated placements ahead of what users are looking for in terms of the regular organic search results. You're probably going to test and do it. We're running our business accordingly. To the second question on sort of Priceline, I'd have to really defer that to them in terms of whether our Instant Book could be having a bearing on their business, point out that they have a really big international business. So impact from us, we have no visibility or little visibility. So I can't really say.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The phase 3 of your plans, improving the shopper experience, maybe boils down to near-term monetization trade-offs to drive long-term engagement and have it, so maybe more of a top line management dynamic there versus Phase 4, which is antitrust is the bo
componenttext: The phase 3 of your plans, improving the shopper experience, maybe boils down to near-term monetization trade-offs to drive long-term engagement and have it, so maybe more of a top line management dynamic there versus Phase 4, which is antitrust is the booking had a choice, which I think involves more marketing e-mail campaigns, push notifications, promotions, maybe call that more OpEx management. Is that the way to think about it? Does phase 4 involve more granular degrees of adjustment in fine-tunings on the dials versus phase 3 -- phase 4 more real-time levers? Can you give us some color there?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. The way we think about the Phase 3 versus Phase 4 is Phase 3 is really about a lot of optimization of the product, and we're very focused on that at the moment, improving the conversion flow, improving how and when we market IB versus meta and
componenttext: Yes, Brian. The way we think about the Phase 3 versus Phase 4 is Phase 3 is really about a lot of optimization of the product, and we're very focused on that at the moment, improving the conversion flow, improving how and when we market IB versus meta and make sure we have excellent improvement in [indiscernible], which, by the way, are continuing to improve that we continue to improve the percentage where we have room prices in IB that at least meet the price in meta. So that's a very operational product-oriented focus that we have. The fourth stage is really about changing user perception. We have traditionally been seen by users as a site that is great as a starting point to go to review then to plan your trip. Increasingly, we are communicating to our users that we're also a great place to book, and that is taking time. That is a repositioning of the brand perception that we have. So that's much more oriented towards how do we communicate that improved offer to our users, which is partly done on our site and it's partly done by communicating with users that have been on our site before, more of a communication opportunity, Phase 3 more of an optimization -- product optimization opportunity.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Nat Schindler with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Nat Schindler with Bank of America.

componenttext: Yes quickly, I don't know if you said anything on this I didn't hear it. How much revenue was shifted into Q3 from Instant Book revenue recognition policy change or effective change?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did not make a specific breakup. I did say earlier on the call that the year-on-year impact of rather the impact on the year-on-year growth was 2% overall. That impact is actually the highest for our vacation rental business, where we discussed earlier
componenttext: We did not make a specific breakup. I did say earlier on the call that the year-on-year impact of rather the impact on the year-on-year growth was 2% overall. That impact is actually the highest for our vacation rental business, where we discussed earlier in the year, we had a shift to more and more transactions that could recognize on state. So that 2% is an overall number we've not broken out further but it's lower for the Hotel segment and higher for the non-hotel segment.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: And I would now like to turn the call back to TripAdvisor's Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Steve Kaufer for any closing remarks.

componenttext: Okay. Well, thanks, everyone, for joining the call. And I want to thank all of our employees around the globe for their continued hard work. We look forward to updating you on our progress next quarter.

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This does conclude the program and you may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded.At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Rela
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Will Lyons. Please go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chelsea. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO.Last night, after market close, we distributed and filed our Q3 earnings release
componenttext:
Thanks, Chelsea. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO.
Last night, after market close, we distributed and filed our Q3 earnings release as well as made available our prepared remarks on our Investor Relations website located at ir.tripadvisor.com. In the release, you will find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call. Also, our IR website contains a supplemental financial information document, which includes certain non-GAAP financial measures discussed on this call as well as other performance metrics.
Instead of reading our prepared remarks on this call, Steve and Ernst will provide a couple of thoughts about the quarter and about our recent progress, and then we'll jump right into Q&A.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that this call may contain estimates and other forward-looking statements that represent the company's view as of today, November 9, 2016. TripAdvisor disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Please refer to our earnings release and our filings with the SEC for information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements.
And with that, I'll pass the call over to you, Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you have had the chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying that we have continued to make nice prog
componenttext:
Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you have had the chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying that we have continued to make nice progress on our key long-term initiatives. As our core content and community assets continue to grow, we are investing to introduce more users to our full suite of travel products and help travelers unlock more experiences and more moments than any other travel brand.
Ernst?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, total revenue grew 1% year-over-year, and growth rates in hotel and non-hotel segments improved modestly compared to our second quarter results. We're still in the very early days at demonstrati
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, total revenue grew 1% year-over-year, and growth rates in hotel and non-hotel segments improved modestly compared to our second quarter results. We're still in the very early days at demonstrating the financial benefit of plugging the monetization leak. However, we continue to see very nice leading indicators of success. We believe this journey will pay off financially, but it will take time. We're moving fast, we're learning, we're improving, and we believe that we're on the best path to maximize long-term growth and shareholder value creation.
With that, I'd like to open up the call for questions.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe with respect to the commentary in the shareholder letter on the investments going forward, so you're starting to lap the impact from the U.S. launch, to lap the impact from the non-U.S. launches through '16 and into '17. But can you help us -- give
componenttext: Maybe with respect to the commentary in the shareholder letter on the investments going forward, so you're starting to lap the impact from the U.S. launch, to lap the impact from the non-U.S. launches through '16 and into '17. But can you help us -- give us some color on what some of those investments are you think are key and the scope of those investments so we can better understand where you find the best and how it might move the needle for broad adoption of idea in the platform as we move into '17?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. I -- so basically, as we continued to lap over the IB rollout, we now get to see more of the benefit of improved revenue per session as opposed to sort of dealing with the decline. As we continue to make our conversion improvements, that al
componenttext: This is Steve. I -- so basically, as we continued to lap over the IB rollout, we now get to see more of the benefit of improved revenue per session as opposed to sort of dealing with the decline. As we continue to make our conversion improvements, that allows us to invest more in pay traffic acquisition. But frankly, we've also built a better product now, and so a lot of the wins that we've had over the past several -- over the past year in terms of conversion flow, in terms of having better pricing in Instant Book, in flexing the interface that we've talked about before, those all come down to enabling our travelers to be able to book better, and that allows us to invest more significantly in pay traffic acquisition. We're developing a better longer-term repeat user model, and we've never been shy about investing for the long term.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first one, you called out some positive comments on Instant Book trends, in particular in September. But when you look at U.S. revenue growth in the third quarter, the oldest market for IB, it looks like it slowed a bit on an easier comp. And
componenttext: I guess the first one, you called out some positive comments on Instant Book trends, in particular in September. But when you look at U.S. revenue growth in the third quarter, the oldest market for IB, it looks like it slowed a bit on an easier comp. And then just kind of sequentially, the revenue per hotel shopper declined from the second quarter to the third quarter on a sequential basis. So can you talk about some of the puts and takes around what's behind some of those metrics?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Ernst. The -- if you look at our core TripAdvisor auction transaction and auction revenues, the U.S. actually sequentially improved quarter-to-quarter and throughout the quarter, both on revenue and revenue per shopper. And what we thought wa
componenttext: Yes. This is Ernst. The -- if you look at our core TripAdvisor auction transaction and auction revenues, the U.S. actually sequentially improved quarter-to-quarter and throughout the quarter, both on revenue and revenue per shopper. And what we thought was a particularly good sign is that now in the third quarter as we cross the point where revenue per shopper and revenue in the U.S. was actually, first, neutral year-on-year and now, in the last months, positive year-on-year. So we thought that was a very good sign because at the end of August, we were lapping the -- a sizable rollout in the U.S. for IB last year, and we feel it's a very good news for us that we see that positive momentum year-on-year. We saw that -- we saw it combined with conversion improvements in the U.S. We saw year-on-year conversion rate improvements on the desktop, IB, on meta. We saw very healthy meta auction dynamics. We saw very healthy IB dynamics. And this gives us a lot of hope that the U.S. now, we were lapping the full rollout of IB a year ago, is in increasingly good shape. You can trust that with outside of the U.S. -- and you see that the growth rates outside of the U.S. are still negative for revenue and revenue per shopper year-on-year as we are not lapping that rollout of IB yet, but we wanted to highlight in our prepared remarks that the U.S. is now in positive territory.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. And a second, if I can, just the prepared remarks imply that even in mobile app, IB is a monetization headwind. So just curious, we would have always thought that it was immediately accretive given poor conversion rates in metasearch and mobile
componenttext: Yes. Okay. And a second, if I can, just the prepared remarks imply that even in mobile app, IB is a monetization headwind. So just curious, we would have always thought that it was immediately accretive given poor conversion rates in metasearch and mobile. So can you maybe give us a little bit more color on the unit economics of IB in mobile and kind of how that's trending?

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This quarter, we made a particular push on the app, and we went to a more dominant display of Instant Booking on the app. And that has had an immediate, in the quarter, negative impact. It's not the same as saying what is just a like-for-like monetization
componenttext: This quarter, we made a particular push on the app, and we went to a more dominant display of Instant Booking on the app. And that has had an immediate, in the quarter, negative impact. It's not the same as saying what is just a like-for-like monetization. We actually quite significantly changed the whole unit -- the UI in the quarter. This had a negative impact in the quarter, but we continue to improve from there. We think that it positions us very well strategically, and we think that with the changes over time, we can get that to positive.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Merwin with Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Merwin with Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the letter, I think you alluded to the ongoing strength of meta, and I was wondering if you could just talk a bit more about how you think about the meta business long term relative to IB. I think in the early stages, at one point, there's an invest
componenttext: So in the letter, I think you alluded to the ongoing strength of meta, and I was wondering if you could just talk a bit more about how you think about the meta business long term relative to IB. I think in the early stages, at one point, there's an investor perception, correct or otherwise, that the IB business would at one point fully overtake meta. But just wanted to hear from you if that is still true a long-term vision for Trip and what these 2 products look like when you get to more of a steady state for Instant Book once you kind of lap and complete the full rollout globally.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Chris. This is Steve. I don't think I would've ever said meta -- I mean, IB would overtake meta. We've always believed, I've always maintained, that meta is an integral part of our value proposition. Travelers want to come to our site. They
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Chris. This is Steve. I don't think I would've ever said meta -- I mean, IB would overtake meta. We've always believed, I've always maintained, that meta is an integral part of our value proposition. Travelers want to come to our site. They get the phenomenal content, information, the trust, the community. And then travelers really wanted to know that they're getting the best price, and meta delivers on that best price. And if the client has a brand loyalty to an OTA or to a supplier direct, and they wish to book on that site, we were fine with that because meta enables that. If the user wants to book on TripAdvisor through Instant Book because we have great price and great content, then that would be a straightforward mechanism and arguably easier on the phone because it's less of a click away. But that when we look at being successful in the eyes of our travelers, it's did we help to find the property they wanted and did we help them book it at the best price, book it on TripAdvisor or book it on our partner sites through meta. So meta remains critical. I don't frankly ever foresee it going away, period, full stop. And then the delta is just over the course of the next several years, where do our consumers choose to go. Do they choose to go into the IB flow because pricing and content and why not and they trust TripAdvisor, well that's fine. If they choose to go into the meta flow, we want to help them book, first and foremost. We obviously recognize that if they actually book on TripAdvisor, they're more likely to come back to TripAdvisor. So we have an inherent interest in that as a flow, but it will never come at the expense of meta going away, at least I wouldn't predict -- ever predict that.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And operationally, we have teams focused on Instant Booking, but we also have teams focused on improving the metasearch auction. This year -- this quarter, we saw nice trends on CPCs in the meta auction. We see good traction for our remarketing product. W
componenttext: And operationally, we have teams focused on Instant Booking, but we also have teams focused on improving the metasearch auction. This year -- this quarter, we saw nice trends on CPCs in the meta auction. We see good traction for our remarketing product. We have some other products that we're rolling out there. So meta is definitely an area where we continue to invest. It's a large part of our revenue and profits, and we're continuing to be focused on making sure that grows attractively.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck with SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck with SunTrust.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rodney for Bob. Two if I could. As we think about 2017, the company investing again in paid marketing channels to sort of grow the funnel, how fast or how much more do you think the shopper growth can reaccelerate to what sort of levels are you lo
componenttext: This is Rodney for Bob. Two if I could. As we think about 2017, the company investing again in paid marketing channels to sort of grow the funnel, how fast or how much more do you think the shopper growth can reaccelerate to what sort of levels are you looking at? And the second question, if I may, you noted in the commentary on the vaulted credit card number. Any sense of what that number has been growing to? That would be helpful.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Hotel shoppers is difficult to forecast for us. There are market and competitive forces at play. We do think that with revenue per shoppers improving into the next year, we will have an opportunity to also spend more. We also believe that spend
componenttext: Thank you. Hotel shoppers is difficult to forecast for us. There are market and competitive forces at play. We do think that with revenue per shoppers improving into the next year, we will have an opportunity to also spend more. We also believe that spending more on marketing may not necessarily only impact hotel shoppers, it may actually help our revenue per shopper as we retarget customers as well. It's very difficult for us to say at this point what exactly the -- our expectation for the impact is, but I do want to underline that we're aiming to affect both metrics.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think another question on the hotel shopper growth because it does remain at a relatively lower level versus where it has been in the past. So I suppose you can't continue to grow 10%, 15% forever, but the current level suggests that there might
componenttext: Steve, I think another question on the hotel shopper growth because it does remain at a relatively lower level versus where it has been in the past. So I suppose you can't continue to grow 10%, 15% forever, but the current level suggests that there might be some sort of a stressful change. So any details you can offer in terms of what might be happening there, especially as the consumer value proposition, the content that you have on the site remains, in my opinion, same as before. And also, I think you saw Priceline write down some of the goodwill for OpenTable. Just wondering if the competitive environment for LaFourchette internationally has shifted meaningfully for you guys.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm not sure I can add much on the hotel shopper. I do kind of reiterate a point Ernst was making in that on the paid marketing side, when you go out booking for new traffic, you can get a combination of traffic that has not been to your site before
componenttext: Sure. I'm not sure I can add much on the hotel shopper. I do kind of reiterate a point Ernst was making in that on the paid marketing side, when you go out booking for new traffic, you can get a combination of traffic that has not been to your site before, which is an increase in monthly hotel shoppers, or you can get traffic that has been to your site before and you're buying them back in remarketing fashion. Those remarketed shoppers aren't going to increase the total number of monthly hotel shoppers, but they are actually pretty important as we try to plug our leak. So for me, I look at the revenue per shopper and how well we are able to monetize the site a bit more than absolute percentage growth of hotel shoppers. It's just the way I look at it. We certainly -- when we look at the stats and you compare them against the competition, we have a lot of hotel shoppers. And several of the other travel categories are just able to monetize them a lot better than we are. To the second question, Priceline writing down OpenTable, well, we've -- OpenTable is certainly a terrific product, has tremendous market share in a number of the markets in which they operate. We've seen them on the ground in Europe or see their attempts. And so we've known or did that they haven't been much of an impact on our business in our core countries in Europe. So the write-down wasn't informative to us.

headline: TripAdvisor Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you'll see that in our total non-hotel segment, we're showing attractive -- continued attractive year-on-year growth, and restaurants is definitely a positive contributor to that.
componenttext: And you'll see that in our total non-hotel segment, we're showing attractive -- continued attractive year-on-year growth, and restaurants is definitely a positive contributor to that.
